[[Domoni]], [[Comoros]]| capacity = | chairman = | manager = | league = [[Comoros Premier League]]| season = 2013| position = 1st| }} '''Association Sportive Komorozine de Domoni''' is a [[Comoros|Comorian]] [[football (soccer)|football]] club located in [[Domoni]], [[Comoros]]. It currently plays in [[Comoros Premier League]].{{cite web|url=http://www.comores-web.com/article/komorozine-leader-a-ndzouani.html|title=Komorozine, leader à Ndzouani|publisher=Comores-web|accessdate=20 October 2010|archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140223041856/http://www.comores-web.com/article/komorozine-leader-a-ndzouani.html|archive-date=2014-02-23|dead-url=yes|df=}} In 2013 the team has won [[Comoros Premier League]]. ==Honours== *'''[[Comoros Premier League]]: 1''' ::2013 ==Performance in CAF competitions== *'''[[CAF Champions League]]: 1 appearance''' ::[[2014 CAF Champions League|2014]] – Preliminary round ==Stadium== Currently the team plays at the [[Stade Oumoini]]. ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *[https://int.soccerway.com/teams/comoros/komorozine/26355 Team profile] - ''soccerway.com'' {{DEFAULTSORT:Komorozine de Domoni, AS}} [[Category:Football clubs in the Comoros]] [[Category:Association football clubs established in 1974]] {{Comoros-sport-stub}} {{Africa-footyclub-stub}}

{{Infobox event | title = Accra Sport Stadium disaster | image = | image_size = | date = May 9, 2001 | place = [[Accra]], [[Ghana]] | reported death(s) = 127 | reported injuries = | cause = police fired [[tear gas]] into the crowd, resulting in a stampede | notes = }}
The '''Accra Sport Stadium disaster''' occurred at the [[Ohene Djan Stadium]], [[Accra]], [[Ghana]] on May 9, 2001. It took the lives of 127 people, making it the worst stadium disaster to have ever taken place in [[Africa]].<ref name="deaths">{{cite news|url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/public_agenda/article.php?ID=1504|title=Prosecution closes case on stadium disaster|date=June 23, 2003|accessdate=August 2, 2012|publisher=Ghanaweb}}{{dead link|date=June 2017|bot=InternetArchiveBot|fix-attempted=yes}}<!-- reserve url: http://www.ghanaweb.com/public_agenda/issue.php?PUBLISHED=2003-06-23&CAT=4{{dead link|date=October 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} --> </ref><ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=http://citifmonline.com/2017/05/09/may-9-victims-remembered-16-yrs-on-herbert-mensah-urges-discipline/|title=May 9 victims remembered 16-yrs on; Herbert Mensah urges discipline|last=Afanyi-Dadzie|first=Ebenezer|date=2017-05-09|website=Ghana News|access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref>
== The tragedy == Ghana's two most successful football teams played that day, the [[Accra Hearts of Oak Sporting Club|Accra Hearts of Oak (The Phobians) Sporting Club]] and the [[Asante Kotoko|Asante Kotoko (Porcupine Warriors) Sporting Club,]]. Officials were anticipating crowd disturbances, and had taken extra security measures. Accra scored two late goals, and a referee called 2–1 Accra, resulting in disappointed Kotoko fans throwing plastic seats and bottles onto the pitch..<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1322433.stm|title=Ghana mourns after football tragedy|date=May 10, 2001|newspaper=BBC|accessdate=August 2, 2012}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1717/editorial/2011/05/09/2477743/may-9-2001-when-the-beautiful-game-became-ugly-in-ghana|title=May 9 2001: When the beautiful game became ugly in Ghana - Goal.com|date=2011-05-09|work=Goal.com|access-date=2017-09-10|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/bmqnbv/fifteen-years-after-africas-deadliest-stadium-disaster-not-much-has-changed|title=Fifteen Years After Africa’s Deadliest Stadium Disaster, Not Much Has Changed|website=Sports|language=en-us|access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref>
The police responded by firing [[tear gas]] into the crowd. Panic and a stampede ensued as fans tried to escape. Gates were locked and the stadium's compromised design left a bottleneck, with fewer exits than originally planned. Ghana Institute of Architects called the stadium a "death trap." After the hour-long ordeal, it was found that 117 deaths resulted from [[compressive asphyxia]] and 10 fans died from trauma.<ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/africa/1322433.stm|title=Ghana mourns after football tragedy|date=May 10, 2001|newspaper=BBC|accessdate=August 2, 2012}}</ref><ref name=":1">{{Cite news|url=http://www.goal.com/en/news/1717/editorial/2011/05/09/2477743/may-9-2001-when-the-beautiful-game-became-ugly-in-ghana|title=May 9 2001: When the beautiful game became ugly in Ghana - Goal.com|date=2011-05-09|work=Goal.com|access-date=2017-09-10|language=en}}</ref><ref name=":2">{{Cite web|url=https://sports.vice.com/en_us/article/bmqnbv/fifteen-years-after-africas-deadliest-stadium-disaster-not-much-has-changed|title=Fifteen Years After Africa’s Deadliest Stadium Disaster, Not Much Has Changed|website=Sports|language=en-us|access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref>
A fan, Abdul Mohammed, had passed out from the tear gas and moved to a morgue, thought to be dead. He became conscious after someone stepped on his foot, narrowly missing a burial.<ref name=":1" />
Reports claim that medical staff had already left the stadium, as the incident happened near the end of the match. Some gates were locked, preventing escape.<ref name="deaths" /><ref name=":0" /><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ghanaweb.com/GhanaHomePage/golf/artikel.php?ID=40742 |title=Investigate the murder of the Ya Na -NDC |date= August 7, 2003 |accessdate = August 2, 2012 |publisher=Ghanaweb }}</ref><ref name=USAT>{{cite news|title=Death toll rises to 126 in Ghana soccer stampede|url=http://usatoday30.usatoday.com/news/world/2001-05-09-stampede.htm|accessdate=6 June 2015|agency=Associated Press|publisher=[[USA Today]]|date=19 June 2001}}</ref><ref name=CNN>{{cite news|title=125 killed in Ghana soccer crush|url=http://www.cnn.com/2001/WORLD/africa/05/09/stadium.stampede/|accessdate=6 June 2015|publisher=[[CNN]]|date=10 May 2001}}</ref>
==Aftermath== An official inquiry blamed police for over-reacting with reckless behaviour and indiscriminate firing of [[plastic bullet]]s and tear gas. It also accused some officers of dishonesty and indefensible laxity. Six police officers were charged with 127 counts of manslaughter. The court ruled that the prosecution had failed to make a case and that the asphyxia may have been caused by the stampede and not the tear gas.<ref name=":2" /><ref name="inquiry">{{cite news|url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/africa/1462508.stm|title=Ghana tragedy: Police to blame|date=July 29, 2001|accessdate=August 2, 2012|publisher=BBC}}</ref>
The commission of inquiry recommended improvements to stadium security and first aid facilities, and that nationwide rapid response teams should be set up.<ref name="inquiry" />
Accra Sports Stadium was renovated in 2007 according to [[FIFA]] standards. Politics may have deferred the National Sports Council's attention to the stadium and 15 years later it again is in disrepair.<ref name=":2" />
== Memorial == Following the event Ghana's president, [[John Kufuor|John Agyekum Kufuor]] called for three days of mourning. The Ghana Premier Football League suspended play for a month.<ref name=":2" /> Since 2001 corporations and philanthropists including former Asante Kotoko chairman from 1999 to 2003, [[Herbert Mensah]], have memorialized this tragedy with a fund, the Stadium Disaster Fund, and a series of events in Kumasi.
The events include paying respects to families of victims, and their 148 children, their invitation to the [[Otumfuo Nana Osei Tutu II|Otumfuo]]'s birthday at [[Manhyia Palace]], prayers in the local Central Mosque, donations to the needy, the laying of a memorial wreath and a memorial march called <nowiki>''May 9th Remembered Street Walk.''</nowiki> In 2016 an annual memorial "May 9th Cup" football competition was created.<ref name=":0" /><ref name=":1" /><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.pulse.com.gh/sports/football/leagues/gpl/may-9-disaster-herbert-mensah-fires-politicians-for-neglect-16-years-on-id6645790.html|title=May 9 Disaster: Herbert Mensah fires politicians for neglect, 16 years on|last=Osei|first=S.K|access-date=2017-09-10|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.myjoyonline.com/sports/2017/May-7th/herbert-mensah-walks-down-may-9-memory-lane-for-16th-time.php|title=Herbert Mensah walks down May 9 memory lane for 16th time|date=2017-05-07|access-date=2017-09-10|language=en-US}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.ghananewsagency.org/sports/ghana-marks-16th-anniversary-of-may-9-disaster-116617|title=Ghana marks 16th Anniversary of May 9 disaster|access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref> Mensah has appealed to the government to memorialize that May 9th, to no agreement.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://citifmonline.com/2017/06/03/herbert-mensah-consoles-june-3-victims/|title=Herbert Mensah consoles June 3 victims|last=Afanyi-Dadzie|first=Ebenezer|date=2017-06-03|website=Ghana News|access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref> In 2017 the memorial events were themed "Embrace the Day."<ref name=":0" />
A bronze statue was erected outside the stadium of a fan carrying another fan to safety with the inscription title, "I Am My Brother's Keeper" in honor of the victims of that tragedy.<ref name=":1" /><ref name=":2" />
Fans who attend matches at the stadium now chant “Never Again”! Never Again!" to remind themselves of that day.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://ghanasoccernet.com/may-9th-stadium-disaster-16-years-on|title=May 9th Stadium Disaster- 16 years on|website=social_image|access-date=2017-09-10}}</ref>
==Similar events== * [[Heysel Stadium disaster]] * [[Hillsborough disaster]]

revision.text:
{{Use dmy dates|date=December 2017}} {{Use Australian English|date=December 2017}} [[File:Stevic bounces the ball.jpg|thumb|right|240px|Umpire [[Matt Stevic]] bounces the ball in a game between [[Carlton Football Club|Carlton]] and [[St Kilda Football Club|St. Kilda]], [[2011 AFL season|2011]].]] A '''ball-up''' (pl. '''ball-ups''') in [[Australian rules football]] describes a method of restarting play at a neutral contest after a stoppage within the field of play. It is not to be confused with a boundary throw-in which occurs in most cases when the ball is forced out of bounds. Ball-ups may be considered to be the equivalent of a [[jump ball]], [[faceoff]] or [[dropped-ball]]. Historically they were performed in most cases by a [[Umpire (Australian rules football)|field umpire]] throwing the ball firmly into the ground such that it bounces directly upwards several metres into the air. They are also known as bouncedowns.
The [[Australian Football League]] amended the rules prior to the 2013 season to instruct the umpires to only bounce the ball at the start of each quarter and after a goal is scored, and throw the ball vertically upwards at all other times.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.abc.net.au/news/2012-10-16/afl-keeps-interchange-uncapped-for-2013/4316160/?site=sport&section=afl|title=AFL keeps interchange uncapped for 2013|date=16 October 2012|publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation|ABC]]}}</ref> Previously throw-ups were only used if ground conditions did not allow for the ball to be bounced effectively, or after a bounced ball-up is poorly executed and recalled (skewing in such a way that only one of the competing ruckmen is able to contest the ball). The skill of being able to bounce an oblong shaped ball vertically upwards on a grass surface is unique to Australian Football and the difficulty has been blamed for deterring some from becoming umpires.<ref>{{cite news|title=A bid to beat bouncedown yips|first=Martin |last=Blake|date=1 May 2003|work=[[The Age]]|url=http://www.theage.com.au/articles/2003/04/30/1051381998497.html}}</ref>
The ball-up executed in the centre circle at the beginning of each quarter and after each [[Goal (sport)|goal]] is known specifically as the ''centre bounce''. Centre bounces are contested by one nominated [[Ruckman (Australian rules football position)|ruckman]] from each team, who attempts to direct the ball to a teammate.
Ball-ups can also occur at other locations around the ground. Umpires often have to decide whether a player tackled while in possession of the ball had a prior opportunity to pass the ball before they were tackled; if so, they will pay a free kick for [[holding the ball]]. If there was no such opportunity, then the umpire will call for a ball-up. Ball-ups are also frequently called when players from both teams scramble for a loose ball and neither can clearly secure possession. At ball-ups which are not centre bounces, other players may help their ruckman in the contest by unexpectedly entering the contest and becoming the ''third man up''.
A ball-up is also called for if a defensive player moves outside of the goal square before kicking the ball back into play following a [[Behind (Australian rules football)|behind]]. In this case, the ball is bounced at the top of the goal square.

Left Center - 372 feet
Center Field - 402 feet
Right Center - 372 feet
Right Field - 340 feet | acreage = | tenants = [[Indiana State University]] (1978-present)
[[Terre Haute Rex]] (2010-present) }} '''Sycamore Stadium''' is a [[baseball stadium]] in [[Terre Haute, Indiana|Terre Haute]], [[Indiana]], [[United States]]. The venue is used by both the [[Indiana State Sycamores baseball]] team of the [[Missouri Valley Conference]] and the [[Terre Haute Rex]] of the [[List of collegiate summer baseball leagues|college summer]] [[Prospect League]]. It has a capacity of 2,500 spectators.{{cite web |title=2010 Quick Facts / Table of Contents |url=http://scholars.indstate.edu/bitstream/10484/1268/1/2010BaseballYearbook.pdf |work=IndState.edu |accessdate=4 June 2012 |archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/68B7vB2cG?url=http://scholars.indstate.edu/bitstream/10484/1268/1/2010BaseballYearbook.pdf |archivedate=2012-06-04 |deadurl=yes |df= }} It hosted the 1982 Missouri Valley Conference Baseball Championship; it routinely serves as a venue for [[Indiana High School Athletic Association|IHSAA]] and [[American Legion Baseball]] tournaments. == Field == Since moving into '''Sycamore Field''' in 1978, [[Indiana State University]] has played over 850 [[baseball]] games at home and posted an outstanding record of 586–268–1 (.686). At the conclusion of the 2009 season, Sycamore Field was completely renovated and renamed '''Bob Warn Field at Sycamore Stadium''' in honor of [[Indiana State University]]'s coach, [[Bob Warn]]. The field is also distinguishable, as it has an infield which is completely artificial turf and an outfield of natural grass. == Facility == The stadium features: * 389 individual chairback seats centered among regular bleacher seats * Locker rooms for the home and visiting teams * A climate-controlled press box * Offices for the head coach and assistants * An indoor hitting facility * Stadium lighting * Infield turf and grass outfield == See also == * [[List of NCAA Division I baseball venues]] == References == {{reflist}} == External links == *[https://web.archive.org/web/20080514110825/http://www.indbaseballhalloffame.org/inductees/warn.html Indiana Baseball Hall of Fame Inductees: Bob Warn, Coach.] *[http://www.gosycamores.com/fls/15200//statistics/09-baseball/BBinsideFront.pdf? Coming 2010: Bob Warn Field at Sycamore Stadium.] *[http://media.www.indianastatesman.com/media/storage/paper929/news/2009/05/26/Sports/Former.Coach.Breaks.Ground.On.New.Baseball.Stadium-3743922.shtml#5 Indiana Statesman: Former coach breaks ground on new baseball stadium.]{{dead link|date=November 2016 |bot=InternetArchiveBot |fix-attempted=yes }} *[https://web.archive.org/web/20090109013621/http://www.indstate.edu/archives/athletics/baseball/fields/sycamore/sycamore.html Indiana State University: Sycamore Field.] {{Missouri Valley Conference baseball venue navbox}} {{Indiana NCAA Division I college baseball venue navbox}} {{Prospect League Ballparks|state=autocollapse}} [[Category:Baseball venues in Indiana]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Indiana State Sycamores baseball]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Terre Haute, Indiana]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Terre Haute, Indiana]] [[Category:1978 establishments in Indiana]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1978]]

revision.text:
{{infobox venue | name = Bragg Memorial Stadium | nickname = | image = [[File:Bragg stadium.jpg|275px|center]] Looking West | fullname = | location = 1500 Wahnish Way
[[Tallahassee, Florida]] 32310 | coordinates = {{coord|30|25|34|N|84|17|30|W|type:landmark|display=it}} | broke_ground = | built = | opened = 1957 | closed = | renovated = 1982 | demolished = | owner = [[Florida A&M University]] | operator = Florida A&M University | surface = AstroTurf RootZone 3D3 | construction_cost = $4 million (renovations) | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Florida A&M Rattlers]] ([[NCAA]]) (1957–present) | capacity = 25,500 |record_attendance=33,954 (1996)}} '''Bragg Memorial Stadium''' is a 25,500-seat football stadium in [[Tallahassee, Florida]], United States. It opened in 1957 and was renovated in 1982. It is home to the [[Florida A&M Rattlers]] [[American Football|football]] team. ==History== Built in 1957, Bragg Memorial Stadium is home to Florida A&M Football. The stadium is named in memory of two of the school's earliest figures in its storied intercollegiate athletic program—the "First Family of Rattler Football"—the father and son combination of Jubie and Eugene Bragg.{{cite web |title=Bragg Memorial Stadium and The Galimore-Powell Field House|url=http://www.famuathletics.com/ViewArticle.dbml?ATCLID=205111949|publisher=Florida A&M University Athletics|accessdate=August 10, 2017}} Jubie Bragg was one of the school's first athletic directors, being one of the key figures in the football program gaining varsity status in 1906. He returned after a brief stint at Tuskegee to become the school's first head football coach and athletic director at FAMU from 1923 to 1925 and again from 1930 to 1932. Bragg's son, Eugene, one of the school's first All-America gridders (1927), took over the reins of the program in 1934, coaching through 1935, when an automobile accident ended his life. Until the stadium's construction in 1957, the Rattlers played on a cow pasture south of the campus and then on a grass field, first known as Bragg Field located on a hill directly behind the current Gaither Gymnasium, where the present track and field complex is located. The field was moved to that location, so that fans could use the bathroom facilities in the nearby dormitories. At the previous location in the cow pasture, it was a walk of a quarter mile to the nearest restroom. However, thanks to appropriations from the Florida Legislature, the all-steel stadium on the campus' westernmost edge was built in 1957. That configuration featured 10,500 permanent seats and bleachers elevated the capacity to 13,200. But by the 1980s, the stadium had fallen into disrepair and had grown too small for the Rattler football program. The 1980 season saw the stadium condemned by the State of Florida engineers, prompting the Legislature (thanks to heavy lobbying by the FAMU Administration) to appropriate over a half million dollars for the stadium's renovation and expansion to begin 1981 with remodeling, to make the stadium suitable for crowds again. To date, the largest single game attendance at Bragg Memorial Stadium was set in 1996 when 33,954 people were in attendance for the Homecoming football game against the Bears of Morgan State University. ===Renovations=== By 1982, the renovation and expansion had made the stadium a 25,500-seat facility with press box elevator, a $125,000 scoreboard with message center, a built-in sprinkler and drainage system, improved restroom, concessions and ticket booths and paved parking areas. The project was completed in 1983, with the unveiling of the Galimore-Powell Fieldhouse, located adjacent to the stadium's south end zone. On March 31, 2017, the Florida A&M Athletics released information about an upcoming proposed renovation to Bragg Memorial Stadium. Upgrades would include, but may not be limited to: new coaches offices, meeting rooms, classrooms and a team meeting room totaling nearly 10,000 square feet. Additionally, renovations would fix certain structural issues that the stadium currently has, including repairing damaged columns in the stadium, as well as repairs to the stairs going into the stands. The proposed upgrades would also include an increase in seating from its current capacity at 25,500, to an improved 35,000, as well as the installation of 25 luxury suites and improvements to the fan experience, which could include better concession stands, retail sales areas and the inclusion of restaurants. No formal date has been set for construction to start on the facility; however, FAMU Athletics officials have stated funding for the improvements will be entirely from fundraising efforts.{{cite web |title=FAMU Mulling a new Bragg Stadium|url=http://urbantallahassee.com/index.php/headlines/item/915-famu-mulling-a-new-bragg-stadium|publisher=Florida A&M University Athletics|date=March 31, 2017|accessdate=August 10, 2017}}{{cite web |title=Design process begins on Bragg Stadium repairs|url=http://www.wctv.tv/content/news/622000-needed-to-repair-Bragg-Memorial-Stadium-406637825.html|publisher=Florida A&M University Athletics|date=March 7, 2017|accessdate=August 10, 2017}} On June 26, 2018, Florida A&M Athletics announced the installation of AstroTurf to the Stadium. It's set to be in place by the beginning of the 2018 season.http://www.famuathletics.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=25300&ATCLID=211719301 '''The Jake Gaither Stadium Plan''' In January 2018 the university released plans to relocate its football stadium to the south side of the campus and renaming it Jake Gaither Stadium. The Jake Gaither Stadium will open to the rest of the new south campus. This new, state-of-the-art establishment will be half dug into the sloping terrain, with a series of terraces accenting the building, allowing for crowds to enter from the campus. During a game, fans have full 360-degree access to the concourse. Rising from the field in three tiers, this 35,000 seat stadium pulls fans as close to the field as possible while keeping optimal site lines. The stadium will remain flexible for other sports such as soccer and lacrosse while featuring 20 Leasable Luxury Suites, 4 Non-leasable University-Utilized Luxury Suites, 16 Lounge Boxes, 1,076 Premium Club Seats and 3,000 Priority Seats.http://constructtwo.com/pinnacle/buildings/ ==Features== The structure contains coaches' offices, conference room, equipment and training/treatment rooms (with X-ray machines), two locker rooms, one for each team, home and visiting, plus an official's locker room and a weight training room. ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FCS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.famuathletics.com/ViewArticle.dbml?DB_OEM_ID=25300&ATCLID=205111949 FAMU Athletic Facilities] {{Florida A&M Rattlers football navbox}} {{FAMU}} {{Mid-Eastern Athletic Conference football venue navbox}} {{Florida college football venues}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Florida A&M Rattlers football]] [[Category:Sports venues in Tallahassee, Florida]] [[Category:Multi-purpose stadiums in the United States]] [[Category:1957 establishments in Florida]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1957]] [[Category:American football venues in Florida]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=January 2014}} {{Use British English|date=January 2014}} The '''Brumbrella''' was a large [[cricket pitch|pitch]] covering used at the [[Edgbaston Cricket Ground]], [[Birmingham]], [[England]] from 1981 to 2001.<ref name=conned>''Cricket: Spectators conned by embarrassing lack of cover'', Jack Bannister, Birmingham Post, 9 July 2001</ref> Its name is a [[portmanteau word]] derived from "[[Brummie|Brum]]"—a nickname for Birmingham, reflecting its location—and "[[umbrella]]", reflecting its function in protecting the pitch from rain.
The Brumbrella was praised and criticised - its speed of deployment helped groundstaff protect the pitch quickly, but as a flat protector, it was prone to "sweating". It was deemed to have contributed to the Edgbaston pitch's deterioration, and its demise was hastened by legislation against flat covers.
It was briefly replaced by "Son of Brumbrella", but today the groundstaff rely on manpower to manoeuvre the covers onto the Edgbaston pitch.
==Description== The Brumbrella comprised a flat rainproof covering which was mechanically unrolled across the playing surface to protect the pitch and most of the outfield from rain. The motorised roller was intended to allow the cover to be rapidly deployed in bad weather, and then removed when the weather improved, so play could continue as quickly as possible,<ref name="ECB">{{cite web| url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci/content/story/77893.html | title=ECB's ban on flat covers hits Brumbrella | date=21 April 1999 | publisher=Cricinfo| accessdate=2009-07-31}}</ref> but this was not always achieved:
{{quote|It stretched from one side of the ground to the other, across the full length of the cricket table and part of the outfield. At the time it was a very innovative piece of equipment, but had its problems. It was so heavy, and took so long to unroll, that it became impractical. By the time it had completed its journey, the shower that it was supposed to be protecting the surface from, had passed, dumping its load on the way! Eventually, when it broke down during a county game, it was decided to return to the more practical method of covering the entire cricket square and run ups with plastic sheeting and roll on roll off covers.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.pitchcare.com/magazine/its-a-cover-up.html | title=It's a cover up! | last=Stretton | first=Bob | date=June–July 2009 | work=Pitchcare Magazine | number=25 | accessdate=2009-07-31}}</ref>}}
The original mechanism, a large section of [[North Sea oil]] pipeline wrapped with a [[tarpaulin]] and weighing some 6 tons, was installed in the winter of 1980 having been designed by Terry Rutter of Sports Ground Consultants. The £43,380 cost was met by the [[Warwickshire County Cricket Club]] Supporters' Association.<ref name=shelter>''Cricket: Brumbrella lends county shelter'', Birmingham Post, 21 February 2001</ref> It was first used during a heavy rain shower in [[England national cricket team|England]]'s second [[One-day International]] against [[Australia national cricket team|Australia]] on 6 June 1981.When the surface water had been removed by the roller wrapped cover, Umpire Dickie Bird met cover designer Terry Rutter on the pitch and said "let's get them back on shall we"?<ref name=shelter/> It was prone to malfunction once the cover fabric had been changed, notably suffering damage on the first day of the [[New Zealand cricket team in England in 1990|1990 Edgbaston Test match]], which prevented its use for the duration of the five-day match.<ref>http://www.espncricinfo.com/wisdenalmanack/content/story/153149.html</ref>
==Anti-moisture policy== In 1999, the [[English Cricket Board|ECB]] introduced a policy against "flat" covers, which can encourage moisture to sweat out of a damp pitch, making batting [[sticky wicket|more difficult]], and opposing captains were given the right to object to its use.<ref name=ECB /> The Brumbrella continued in use for a little while longer, but, after 20 years of use, it was replaced in early 2001.<ref name=ECB /> Parts were given away to Warwickshire clubs to use as covers, including Moseley Ashfield,<ref name=shelter /> and a "massive section" was acquired by Atherstone Town Cricket Club.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.atherstonecc.co.uk/htm/season2001preview.htm |title=2001 Season Preview |publisher=Atherstone Town Cricket Club |accessdate=2009-07-31 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20050227010538/http://www.atherstonecc.co.uk/htm/season2001preview.htm |archivedate=27 February 2005 }}</ref> The Brumbrella was also blamed, in part, for a deterioration in the condition of the Edgbaston pitch.
==Replacement== The new mechanism—dubbed "Son of Brumbrella"<ref name=shelter />—cost around £80,000 and was much lighter, weighing only one ton.<ref name=ECB /> It had two motorised rollers, housed in trenches on either side of the outfield, and was operated by remote control. However, it proved temperamental in use, and malfunctioned several times.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cricinfo.com/ci//content/story/102712.html|title=Ostler enlivens another day of attrition at Edgbaston|last=Sheldon|first=John|date=2001-06-02|publisher=Cricinfo|accessdate=2009-07-31}}</ref> It failed before the first [[County Championship]] match of the season against [[Hampshire County Cricket Club|Hampshire]] on 20–23 April, and a second time on 2 June, during the third day of Warwickshire's third home Championship match against [[Gloucestershire County Cricket Club|Gloucestershire]], and the groundstaff returned to manual covers for England's One-day International against [[Pakistan national cricket team|Pakistan]] on 7 June.<ref>''Cricket: Brumbrella facing Edgbaston exit'', Ian Willars, Birmingham Evening, 4 June 2001</ref><ref>''Cricket: Brumbrella ruled out for one-dayer'', Birmingham Evening Mail, 5 June 2001</ref> However, the groundstaff struggled to deploy and remove manual covers quickly during the rain-affected [[the Ashes|Ashes Test]] on 5–8 July 2001.<ref name=conned /> The new Brumbrella was abandoned later that year and returned to its manufacturers, Tildenet, who refunded its cost to Warwickshire.<ref name=delay>Cricket: Warwicks delay move on cover at Edgbaston, ''[[Birmingham Post]]'', 9 January 2002.</ref> Edgbaston groundsman [[Steve Rouse]] subsequently explained that it became too heavy to use once it was covered with water.<ref>''Cricket: Pitch perfect and swing bowling'', George Dobell, Birmingham Post, 17 May 2007</ref> Edgbaston now boasts a new rain protection system called a "Hover Cover" based on the Hovercraft principle, that covers the wicket only but also has flaps that roll out on four sides to also protect the rest of the cricket square, as seen live on UK television 7 August 2010, England v Pakistan 2nd test at Edgbaston<ref>David Lloyd commentary from Sky's coverage</ref>
==Legacy== Since the Brumbrella's demise, Edgbaston officials have been "unable to find a suitable replacement they now have to rely on the fast legged groundsmen."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/weather/sports/features/cricket2.shtml | title=Cricket and the Weather | work=[[BBC Weather]] | publisher=[[BBC]] | accessdate=2009-07-31}}</ref> On a [[Test cricket|Test match]] day, Rouse's "normal staff of six rises to around 20, the extra hands principally used for getting the pitch covers on and off quickly."<ref>{{cite web| url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/sport1/low/cricket/the_ashes/1414119.stm | title=Pitching in for the Ashes | last=Beauchamp | first=Steve | date=2001-06-29 |publisher=[[BBC]] | work =[[BBC Sport Online]] |accessdate=2009-07-31}}</ref>
Despite having been retired in 2001, the Brumbrella remains a point of reference for the efficient covering of cricket pitches: [[Derek Pringle]] in ''The Daily Telegraph'' and [[Mike Selvey]] in ''The Guardian'' both favourably compared the efficient performance of the groundstaff at [[Kandy]] during England's Test match against [[Sri Lanka national cricket team|Sri Lanka]] in December 2007 to it.<ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/columnists/derekpringle/2327324/England-let-chance-slip-in-Sri-Lanka.html | title=England let chance slip in Sri Lanka| last=Pringle| first=Derek| newspaper=[[Daily Telegraph]] | date=2007-12-03 | accessdate=2009-07-31}}</ref><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.theguardian.com/sport/2007/dec/03/cricket.englandcricketseries | title=Murali's menace offers ominous pointers for England| last=Selvey| first=Mike| newspaper=[[The Guardian]] | date=2007-12-03| accessdate=2009-07-31}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}
