1 Penalty applies to fouls in excess of four in a regulation period or in excess of three in an overtime period. If a team has not committed its foul quota by the two minute mark of a period, it shall be allowed one foul before the penalty applies. Offensive fouls do not count toward this total.
2 Defensive fouls committed during an inbounds pass prior to the ball being released result in two free throws regardless of the penalty situation.
3 In the NBA, a team must have five players on the court at all times. If a team is down to five players because of injuries and players with six fouls, and a player commits his sixth foul, he remains in the game and a technical foul is charged. The technical foul penalty of one free throw and the ball applies. ===Historical=== Prior to the 1954–55 season, the NBA established the rule that a backcourt foul would result in a "three to make two" situation (up to three attempts to make two free throws) if the violating team was over the team foul limit.{{cite web| title=NBA.com: NBA Rules History| url=http://www.nba.com/analysis/rules_history.html| accessdate=2011-04-04| deadurl=no| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110303213838/http://www.nba.com/analysis/rules_history.html| archivedate=2011-03-03| df=}} By 1979, the rule had been extended to the penalty situation for flagrant fouls, fouls made in the act of shooting (resulting in a miss), and fouls due to the swinging of the elbows.{{Cite book| last = Winick | first = Matt | title = Official 1979–80 National Basketball Association Guide | publisher = The Sporting News | year = 1979 | page = Rules Index 31 |url=https://books.google.com/books?id=CoWrPQAACAAJ| isbn = 0-89204-049-1}} Prior to the 1981–82 season, this rule and the related "two to make one" rule were abolished. In 1956, in response to reports that Wilt Chamberlain was able to dunk free throws, the NCAA established a rule requiring that free throw shooters keep both feet behind the free throw line during an attempt.{{citation |title=That Stilt, Wilt, Responsible For 2 Rule Changes; Kansas' Chamberlain Even Dunked His Foul Shots | newspaper=[[Toledo Blade]] |date=November 28, 1956}} The NBA later adopted this rule.{{Cite book| last = Silverman | first = Drew | title = Kansas Jayhawks | publisher = Sportszone| year = 2012 | page = 21 | isbn = 978-1617832833}} ==Strategy== [[File:Tirs lliures.ogv|thumb|250px|right|Free throwing at a [[Valencia Basket]] match.]] As mentioned earlier, some players are notoriously bad free throw shooters. Historical examples of star players who were poor shooters include Wilt Chamberlain, Ben Wallace, and Shaquille O'Neal.{{cite web | url=https://www.sbnation.com/longform/2012/12/13/3758698/rick-barry-underhand-free-throw-nba | title=Shooting for Perfection | work=SB Nation | date=2012-12-13 | accessdate=December 16, 2012 | author=Fixler, Kevin | deadurl=no | archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20121216014212/http://www.sbnation.com/longform/2012/12/13/3758698/rick-barry-underhand-free-throw-nba | archivedate=December 16, 2012 | df= }} This allows a strategy where a team intentionally fouls this player, hoping that they will miss one or both shots and the defending team will re-gain possession of the ball. This strategy was dubbed [[Hack-a-Shaq]] when famously used on Shaquille O'Neal. Dwight Howard, DeAndre Jordan and Andre Drummond{{cite web|url=http://espn.go.com/video/clip?id=15415006|title=Does Hack-a-Shaq actually work?|publisher=ESPN|date=April 28, 2016|accessdate=June 20, 2016|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20160625180538/http://espn.go.com/video/clip?id=15415006|archivedate=June 25, 2016|df=}} has been subjected to this strategy as well,{{cite web|last=Landman|first=Seth|title='Hack-a-Howard' strategy in full effect|url=http://espn.go.com/fantasy/blog/_/name/boxscore_basketball/id/7458162/dwight-howard-busy-night-free-throw-line-not-helpful-fantasy-owners|publisher=ESPN|accessdate=21 May 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120228185459/http://espn.go.com/fantasy/blog/_/name/boxscore_basketball/id/7458162/dwight-howard-busy-night-free-throw-line-not-helpful-fantasy-owners|archivedate=28 February 2012|df=}} as have [[Hack-a-Shaq#Application against other players|other players]]. It can be advantageous for a trailing team to intentionally foul late in a close game. While this allows the leading team to shoot free throws and increase their lead, it also stops the clock, similar to a time out in [[Gridiron football|football]] (in basketball, a time out may only be called by a team with possession of the ball). As well, it allows the trailing team the chance to take possession if the second free throw is missed, and if it is made awards possession outright to the trailing team. Therefore, many teams substitute players with high free throw percentages when they are leading late in games to combat this strategy. It is seen as a last resort strategy with little chance of success, but if it is not employed the leading team may run out the clock and end the game. As well, a defensive team leading by three may foul an offensive team intentionally late in the game, if the game clock is no greater than a couple of seconds. In such circumstances, the opposing team would most likely not have enough time for multiple possessions. Down three points, the opposing team's obvious strategy would be to attempt a [[three-point field goal|three-pointer]] to try to send the game into overtime; however, the leading team may attempt to foul the trailing team before a shot is attempted, as this would lead to only two free throws which is not enough to tie the game. If the trailing team is placed into the situation of shooting two free throws, they must attempt to intentionally miss the second free throw in the hopes of securing the offensive rebound (which is harder than normal with free throws, as the defending team is automatically given position) and scoring before the game clock expires – if the first free throw is made, a two-pointer would tie the game, and a three-pointer would win the game; if the first free throw is missed, only a three-pointer would tie the game. Theoretically, adopting this strategy makes a leading team four times more likely to win the game than allowing the trailing team to attempt a three-pointer.{{cite web|last=Lawhorn|first=Adrian|title="3-D": Late-Game Defensive Strategy with a 3-Point Lead|url=http://www.82games.com/lawhorn.htm|publisher=82games.com|accessdate=21 May 2012|deadurl=no|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120504045529/http://82games.com/lawhorn.htm|archivedate=4 May 2012|df=}} ==Technique== The majority of adult professional players shoot free throws in the overhand style, despite both theoretical and practical demonstrations that the underhand style (aka "granny-style") usually produces better average results.{{cite web |url=http://discovermagazine.com/2008/the-body/07-physics-proves-it-everyone-should-shoot-granny-style |first=Curtis |last=Rist |title=Physics Proves It: Everyone Should Shoot Granny-Style |publisher=[[Discover (magazine)|Discover]] |date=2008-08-07 |accessdate=2017-01-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170202012458/http://discovermagazine.com/2008/the-body/07-physics-proves-it-everyone-should-shoot-granny-style |archivedate=2017-02-02 |df= }}{{cite web |url=http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/basketball/ct-granny-shot-nba-free-throw-20161228-story.html |first=Adam |last=Kilgore |title='Granny' shot master Rick Barry is glad someone had the guts to bring it back to the NBA |publisher=[[Chicago Tribune]] |date=2016-12-28 |accessdate=2017-01-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20170119125235/http://www.chicagotribune.com/sports/basketball/ct-granny-shot-nba-free-throw-20161228-story.html |archivedate=2017-01-19 |df= }} Famously, in the NBA, [[Rick Barry]] retired in 1980 while ranked first in NBA history at the time with his 0.900 free throw percentage.{{cite web |url=http://www.nba.com/history/players/barry_bio.html |title=Rick Barry |publisher=Turner Sports Interactive, Inc. |work=NBA.com |accessdate=2017-01-22 |deadurl=no |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20100317133934/http://www.nba.com/history/players/barry_bio.html |archivedate=2010-03-17 |df= }} There were only a few professional players who have utilized this technique, while the vast majority of them resisted adopting the technique for the fear of ridicule or for other similar reasons unrelated to performance. ==See also== *[[50–40–90 Club]], exclusive group of players with one criterion including shooting at least 90% of free throws *[[List of National Basketball Association career free throw scoring leaders]] *[[List of NCAA Division I men's basketball career free throw scoring leaders]] ==References== ;Notes {{reflist|30em}} ==External links== {{commons category|Free throw}} * [http://www.nba.com/analysis/rules_12.html?nav=ArticleList NBA Rule Number 12: Fouls and Penalties] * {{SuprisinglyAwesome|2-free-throws|Free Throws}} {{basketball}} {{Basketball statistics}} {{Infobox venue | stadium_name = Glacier Ice Rink | nickname = | image = | location = 1101 South Ave West [[Missoula, Montana|Missoula]], [[Montana]]
{{USA}} | coordinates = | broke_ground = 1996 | opened = {{start date and years ago|1996|10|10}} | closed = | demolished = | owner = Missoula Area Youth Hockey Association | operator = Missoula Area Youth Hockey Association | surface = Ice Rink | construction_cost = Unknown | capacity = 1,000 | architect = | former_names = | tenants = Missoula Bruins ([[North American 3 Hockey League|NA3HL]]) (2016–present)
[[Missoula Maulers]] ([[Northern Pacific Hockey League|NorPac]]/[[American West Hockey League|AWHL]]/[[Western States Hockey League|WSHL]]) (2007–16)
Missoula Figure Skating Club
Missoula Curling Club
Missoula Referees Association
Women's Hockey Association of Missoula }} The '''Glacier Ice Rink''' is a two-sheet ice arena located in [[Missoula, Montana]]. It is operated by the Missoula Area Youth Hockey Association (MAYHA), a non profit organization whose mission is to "provide recreational opportunities for learning and playing the game of hockey and other ice skating activities for children and adults in our community." The rink is open 10 months a year and offers youth and adult hockey leagues, hockey tournaments and public skating sessions. Glacier Ice Rink is also home to the Missoula Figure Skating Club, the Missoula Curling Club, the Missoula Referees Association, and the Women's Hockey Association of Missoula (WHAM). From 2007 to 2016, it was also home to the [[Missoula Maulers]] junior hockey team before the team owner and MAYHA had a contract dispute and the team was shut down.{{cite web |url=http://missoulian.com/sports/local/maulers-owner-explains-decision-to-disband-local-hockey-team/article_2be5c1a1-e393-5807-b053-b5191d356423.html |title=Maulers owner explains decision to disband local hockey team |publisher=''[[The Missoulian]]'' |date=May 14, 2016}} The Maulers' owner Michael Burks had installed all the bleachers at the ice rink with his own funding, so after failing to negotiate a new contract, he removed the bleachers, forcing Glacier Ice Rink to raise funds for replacement seating.{{cite web|url=http://missoulanews.bigskypress.com/missoula/junior-hockey/Content?oid=3139752|title=Bruins drop the puck|date=September 22, 2016|publisher=''[[Missoula Independent]]''}} The Maulers were quickly replaced with an expansion team in the [[North American 3 Hockey League]] named the [[Missoula Jr. Bruins]] with new owners Jason and Liz DiMatteo.{{cite web |url=http://mtstandard.com/sports/hockey/new-missoula-junior-hockey-team-approved/article_079a2c9e-443a-5247-bb4c-1f82f7fcd6a3.html |title=New Missoula junior hockey team approved |publisher=''[[The Montana Standard]]'' |date=May 21, 2016}} ==Tenants== *Missoula Area Youth Hockey Association (MAYHA) *Missoula Jr. Bruins - NA3HL *Missoula Figure Skating Club *Missoula Curling Club *Missoula Referees Association *Womens Hockey Association of Missoula (WHAM) ===Previous tenants=== *[[Missoula Maulers]] ==References== {{Reflist}} ==External links== *{{official website|http://www.glaciericerink.com/}} {{Missoula, Montana}} {{coord|46.848708|-114.014763|type:landmark_globe:earth_region:US-MT|display=title}} [[Category:1996 establishments in Montana]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1996]] [[Category:Sports venues in Missoula, Montana]] [[Category:Indoor ice hockey venues in Montana]]

{{Motorsport venue |Name = Islip Speedway |Nicknames ="World Famous Islip Speedway" |Time = GMT-5 |Location = [[Islip (town), New York|Islip]], [[New York (state)|New York]] |Coordinates = |Image = [[File:IslipSpeedway19471984.jpg|250px]] |Image_caption = Islip Speedway (from an aerial view) |Capacity = |Owner = |Operator = |Broke_ground = |Opened = 1947 |Closed = 1984 |Construction_cost= |Architect = |Former_names = |Events = [[Sprint Cup Series|Grand National Series]] (now called Monster Energy NASCAR Cup Series) |Layout1 = Oval
Figure 8 |Surface = |Length_km = .32 |Length_mi = .2 |Miles_first = true |Turns = 4 |Banking = }} '''Islip Speedway''' was a .2-mile (320-meter) oval [[race track]] in [[Islip (hamlet), New York|Islip]], [[New York (state)|New York]] which was open from 1947 until 1984.{{cite web | author=Goldsmith, Paul | title=Gauge Nears 'E' at Riverhead Raceway | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2003/08/31/nyregion/gauge-nears-e-at-riverhead-raceway.html | work=[[The New York Times]] | publisher= | date=2003-08-31 | accessdate=2009-05-17}} It is the smallest track ever to host [[NASCAR]]'s [[Grand National Series]] (now the Sprint Cup Series),{{cite web | author=Aumann, Mark | title=Countdown: New York | url=http://www.nascar.com/2006/news/headlines/cup/01/31/countdown.daytona.ny/index.html | work=[[NASCAR]] | publisher= | date=2006-01-31 | accessdate=2009-05-18}}{{cite web|author=London, Gary |title=NASCAR Has A Long History Racing In The Northeast |url=http://www.nationalspeedsportnews.com/columns/gary-london/nascar-has-a-long-history-racing-in-the-northeast |work=[[National Speed Sport News]] |publisher= |date= |accessdate=2009-05-18 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080908033426/http://www.nationalspeedsportnews.com/columns/gary-london/nascar-has-a-long-history-racing-in-the-northeast/ |archivedate=September 8, 2008 }} from 1964 to 1971. The first [[demolition derby]] took place at Islip Speedway in 1958. The idea was patented by Larry Mendelson, who worked at Islip Speedway. ==Demolition Derby== Islip Speedway is credited with hosting the first [[demolition derby]],{{cite web | author=Macdonald, Brady | title=Some Cars' Road to Ruin Leads to O.C. Fair | url=http://articles.latimes.com/2001/jul/21/local/me-25039?s=wk&n=o&rd=en.wikipedia.org&sessid=76d1facb3a07c9456cc53f580ecd034870054b83&uuid=76d1facb3a07c9456cc53f580ecd034870054b83&pg=2&pgtp=article&eagi=&cat=local&pe_id=4469148&page_type=article&exci=2001%7C07%7C21%7Clocal%7Cme-25039 | work=[[Los Angeles Times]] | publisher= | date=2001-07-21 | accessdate=2009-05-17}} which took place in 1958.{{cite web | author=LeDuff, Charlie | title=Vroooom! Kapow! Smash! C-r-r-runch!; At Riverhead Demo Derby, the Race, Such as It Is, Goes to the Durable | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2000/06/18/nyregion/vroooom-kapow-smash-c-r-r-runch-riverhead-demo-derby-race-such-it-goes-durable.html | work=[[The New York Times]] | publisher= | date=2000-06-18 | accessdate=2009-05-17}} According to Larry Mendelsohn, he originated the idea after realizing that spectators enjoyed watching the cars crash more than the races.{{cite web | author=Martin, Douglas | title=Demolition Derby Survives on Long Island And So Do Participants, Despite Themselves | url=https://www.nytimes.com/1996/09/13/nyregion/demolition-derby-survives-long-island-so-participants-despite-themselves.html | work=[[The New York Times]] | publisher= | date=1996-09-13 | accessdate=2009-05-19}} However, there are alternative accounts to the origins of demolition derby. One source claims that Don Basile invented the demolition derby at Carrell Speedway in 1947.{{cite web|url=http://www.popularmechanics.com/automotive/motorsports/1268911.html?page=3 |title=Demolition Derby PM Style |last=Delaney |first=Bill |date=April 1999 |publisher=[[Popular Mechanics]] |accessdate=2009-05-25 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090630120811/http://www.popularmechanics.com/automotive/motorsports/1268911.html?page=3 |archivedate=2009-06-30 |df= }} The [[American Broadcasting Company|ABC]] television show ''[[Wide World of Sports (U.S. TV series)|Wide World of Sports]]'' broadcast demolition derbies at Islip Speedway beginning in the early 1960s.{{cite web | author=[[The Associated Press]] | title=Demolition Derbies Are Still a Popular Attraction at Racetracks | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2008/09/07/sports/othersports/07demolition.html?_r=1&ref=todayspaper | work=[[The New York Times]] | publisher= | date=2008-09-06 | accessdate=2009-05-17}} This exposure gave the event national attention and helped increase its popularity. ==Figure 8== In 1962 a [[Figure 8 racing|Figure 8 track]] was added. The Figure 8 course shared the north and south turns with the oval and crisscrossed using lanes paved through the infield. The first Figure 8 race was held on August 11, 1962. The popular Figure 8 class became a regularly featured division from the time of its inception until the track's final date of operation September 8, 1984. In 1964 track promoter Larry Mendelsohn conceived the idea of hosting the first "Figure 8 World Championship" event and sold his idea to ABC-TV, who would film the daytime event for broadcast at a later date on their popular Saturday afternoon television show, "ABC's Wide World of Sports". To draw out-of-town competitors, Mendelsohn would guarantee a starting spot in the feature event to all Figure 8 division track champions who would travel to Long Island and represent their home track, hoping to claim the title of "World Champion". The remaining starting positions were determined through heat races. The "Demolition Derby World Championship" was held immediately following the "Figure 8 World Championship" feature race and was also taped for future broadcast on "ABC's Wide World of Sports". These broadcasts led to increased exposure and notoriety of the track, which came to be known as "World Famous Islip Speedway". Figure 8 drivers who won the title and were crowned "Figure 8 World Champion" at Islip were: 1963- Larry Wood, Northport, NY; 1964-Benny Giaraputo, West Islip, NY; 1965-Art Cox, Anderson, IN; 1966-Forrest Halliburton, Indianapolis, IN; 1967-Richie Gomes, Brentwood, NY; 1968-Richard Simmons, Plymouth, MI; 1969-Aaron Coller, Tampa, FL; 1970-Lester Slone, Pinellas Park, FL; 1971 & 1973-Sonny Thompson, Indianapolis, IN; 1972- Mike Pinchuk, Bay Shore, NY; 1974 & 1975-Carl Voelker, Islip NY; 1976 & 1979-Chuck Hall, Toledo, OH; 1977-Quinn Vollgraff, Ronkonkoma, NY; 1978-Allen Brock, Medford, NY; 1980-Eddie Sutton, Crownville, MD; 1981, 1982 & 1983-Doug Huber, Bellport, NY; 1984-Chuck Hlatky, Ronkonkoma, NY. ==NASCAR racing== Islip Speedway hosted six [[NASCAR]] races from 1964 to [[1971 Islip 250|1971]], skipping the years 1969 and 1970. [[Richard Petty]] won the last NASCAR race at Islip{{cite web | author=Wallmuller, Bill | title=Islip Speedway - Local Auto Racing 1947-1984 Genesis Of Some Great Auto Racing Trivia | url=http://www.auto-racing-sports.com/racing_trivia_contributions.html | work=Merokee's Auto Racing Sports | publisher=Merokee Enterprises | year=2007 | accessdate=2009-05-18}}{{cite web | author=Caraviello, David | title=No racetrack? Then take it to the streets | url=http://www.nascar.com/2008/news/opinion/09/10/dcaraviello.new.york.race/index.html | work=[[NASCAR]] | publisher= | date=2008-09-10 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} by two laps.{{cite web | author=Swan, Raygan | title=Johnson chasing Petty's record for five consecutive | url=http://www.nascar.com/2007/news/headlines/cup/11/16/jjohnson.rpetty.five.consecutive/index.html | work=[[NASCAR]] | publisher= | date=2007-11-16 | accessdate=2009-05-18}} Others who have won at Islip include [[Bobby Allison]] and [[Billy Wade (NASCAR)|Billy Wade]]. NASCAR stopped coming to Islip Speedway when the organization axed all races shorter than {{convert|250|mi|km}} from its schedule. ==Gallery== Image:M10JohnnyCoyIslip.jpg|Legendary race driver Johnny Coy at Islip Speedway behind the wheel of the Vitucci midget number 10. Car owner Angelo Vitucci is standing (second from left). Image:1972LesterSlone136.jpg|1970 Figure 8 World Champion Lester Slone of Pinellas Park, FL at Islip Speedway, 1972. Image:1974RichardSimmons771.jpg|1968 Figure 8 World Champion "Li'l Richard" Simmons of Plymouth, MI at Islip Speedway, 1974. Image:BobWaas6.jpg|9A Modified driven by Bobby Holmberg at Islip Speedway. ==See also== *[[List of auto racing tracks in the United States]] *[[Short track motor racing]] ==References== {{reflist|33em}} ==External links== {{Commons category|Figure 8 racing}} *[http://www.melaniff.com/speedway/ Islip Speedway (Memorial Website)] *[http://www.eastislip.org/Pages/Islip%20Speedway/Islip%20Airport%20&%20Speedway.htm Islip Airport & Speedway (East Islip Historical Society)] *[http://www.airfields-freeman.com/NY/Airfields_NY_LongIs_Suffolk_W.htm#islip (Original) Islip Airport, Islip, NY (Abandoned and Little-Known Airfields)] {{coord|40.7495|N|73.2115|W|display=title}} [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1947]] [[Category:1984 disestablishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Defunct motorsport venues in the United States]] [[Category:Motorsport venues in New York (state)]] [[Category:Islip (town), New York]] [[Category:NASCAR tracks]] [[Category:Sports venues in Long Island]] [[Category:1947 establishments in New York (state)]] [[Category:Sports venues in Suffolk County, New York]]

revision.text:
"'''Kapa o Pango'''" is a prematch [[Haka (sports)|haka]] or challenge unique to the [[New Zealand national rugby union team]], the All Blacks. Since 2005 the "Kapa o Pango" haka has been performed before [[Test match (rugby union)|rugby test matches]] by the All Blacks as an alternative to the usual "[[Ka Mate]]" haka. The longest sequence of "Kapa o Pango" performances is four, which occurred in 2014.
[[File:Rugby world cup 2011 NEW ZEALAND ARGENTINA (7309674588).jpg|350px|thumbnail|right|All Blacks performing "Kapa o Pango" in 2011]]
==History== In August 2005, before the Tri-Nations test match between New Zealand and South Africa at [[Carisbrook]] stadium in Dunedin, New Zealand, performed a new haka, "Kapa o Pango", specially composed by Derek Lardelli and "...designed to reflect the multi-cultural make-up of contemporary New Zealand{{snd}}in particular the influence of [[Polynesian culture|Polynesian]] cultures".<ref name="KapaoPango">{{cite news|url=http://www.nzherald.co.nz/section/4/story.cfm?c_id=4&objectid=10342926 |title=New haka the cutting edge of sport |work= NZ Herald |date=29 August 2005 |accessdate=14 June 2008 |last=Stokes |first=Jon}}</ref> "Kapa o Pango" was to be performed on special occasions and was not intended to replace "Ka Mate".<ref name="KapaoPango"/>
[[John Smit]], the Springbok captain who faced the debut performance of "Kapa o Pango", said after the match: "To stand there and watch it for the first time was a privilege."<ref name="KapaoPango"/> ''The Daily Telegraph'' columnist Mick Cleary criticised the new haka as "unmistakably provocative … There is a fine line and the All Blacks crossed it. Carisbrook is a rugby field not a back-street alley."<ref>{{cite news |last=Cleary |first=Mick |url=https://www.telegraph.co.uk/sport/main.jhtml?xml=/sport/2005/09/06/srmick06.xml&sSheet=/portal/2005/09/06/ixportal.html |title=Cut-throat haka does All Blacks no favours |date=6 September 2005 |publisher=The Daily Telegraph |accessdate=2006-08-24 | location=London }}</ref> [[France national rugby union team|French]] coach [[Bernard Laporte]] requested New Zealand not to perform "Kapa o Pango" during their November 2006 tour of France, claiming that "It's no good for the promotion of our sport."<ref>{{cite news |last=Matheson |first=John |url=http://www.stuff.co.nz/stuff/sundaynews/0,2106,3755968a15599,00.html |title=French weigh in to haka debate |date=6 August 2006 |publisher=Sunday News |accessdate=2006-08-24 }}</ref>{{Dead link|date=October 2010|bot=H3llBot}}
On 24 September 2011, for their [[2011 Rugby World Cup Pool A|Pool A]] match against France at [[Eden Park]], the All Blacks performed "Kapa o Pango", which included the act of drawing the thumb across the throat at the end. The French had ousted New Zealand at the [[2007 Rugby World Cup knockout stage|2007 World Cup]]. It had since been a fixture since the knockout stages against Argentina and Australia.
==Controversy== "Kapa o Pango" concludes with what has been interpreted as a "[[Taunting#Cutthroat|throat slitting]]" gesture that led to accusations that "Kapa o Pango" encourages violence, and sends the wrong message to All Blacks fans.<ref name="two">{{cite web |work=[[The Age]] |publisher=Fairfax |location=Australia | title=All Blacks coach slams haka criticism | url=http://www.theage.com.au/news/Sport/All-Blacks-coach-slams-haka-criticism/2006/07/28/1153816359796.html| accessdate=17 January 2007 |date=28 July 2006}}</ref> However, according to Lardelli, the gesture represents "drawing vital energy into the heart and lungs".<ref name="GestureMeaning">{{cite web | url=http://tvnz.co.nz/view/page/454218/779048 |title=New haka gets public approval |publisher= [[TVNZ]] |date=8 July 2006 |accessdate=4 January 2008}}</ref>
The All Blacks opted not to perform "Kapa o Pango" in their opening test of 2006 against {{nrut|Ireland}}. It was requested that they perform their usual "Ka Mate" haka while a review was conducted into "Kapa o Pango".<ref>{{cite web|title=Life is precious, live it to da fullest...! |url=http://souvenjawaven89.blogspot.co.nz/2008/09/rugbykamate-kamate-all-blacks-haka.html |accessdate=21 October 2015}}</ref> The throat-slitting action at the end of "Kapa o Pango" had drawn many complaints in the lead-up to the Irish test, with members of the public complaining about it to the [[NZRU]]. The NZRU said that it was not because of public pressure that it was not performed against Ireland.
In the run-up to the first All Blacks Test of the [[2006 Tri Nations Series|2006 Tri Nations]] at [[Jade Stadium]] in Christchurch against {{nrut|Australia}}, the NZRU completed their review, and concluded that the gesture had a radically different meaning within [[Māori culture]] and haka traditions, indicating the drawing of "''[[hauora]]''", the breath of life into the heart and lungs. As a result, "Kapa o Pango" was performed, complete with the final gesture, before the Australia test.
Despite this, the controversial gesture was withdrawn in 2007, with a modified action (raking the right arm from the left hip to over the right shoulder) performed in the challenge when "Kapa o Pango" was performed in test matches against France and South Africa. During the [[2008 Tri Nations series]], the All Blacks appear to have reverted to the original action of drawing the hand across the throat.
==Players who have led performances== One All Blacks player is assigned in each test match to lead the haka. Although the leader is often of [[Māori people|Maori]] descent, this is not compulsory as several players have [[Polynesians|Polynesian]] heritage. Since its introduction in 2005 the following players have led Kapa o Pango (number in brackets represents tests player has led): * [[Piri Weepu]] (25) * [[Liam Messam]] (12) * [[Keven Mealamu]] (7) * [[TJ Perenara]] (6) * [[Rico Gear]] (3) * [[Tana Umaga]] (2) * [[Carl Hayman]] (2) * [[Aaron Smith (rugby union)|Aaron Smith]] (3) * [[Hosea Gear]] (1)
==See also== * [[List of New Zealand rugby union haka performances]] – since the introduction of "Kapa o Pango"
==References== {{reflist}}
{{Culture of Oceania}}
[[Category:Ritual dances]] [[Category:Māori culture]] [[Category:Haka]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Kinnick Stadium | nickname = | image = Kinnick Stadium Press Box.jpg | image_size = 300px | address = 886 Stadium Drive | location = [[Iowa City, Iowa]] | coordinates = {{coord|41|39|31|N|91|33|4|W|type:landmark|display=inline,title}} | broke_ground = March 6, 1929 | opened = October 5, 1929 | expanded = 1956, 1983, 1990 | renovated = 2006, 2017-2019 | closed = | demolished = | owner = Iowa Hawkeye Athletics | operator = The University of Iowa | surface = [[FieldTurf]] (2009–present)
[[Astroturf]] (1972–1988)
Grass (1929–1971, 1989–2008) | construction_cost = $497,151.42 (initial construction)
(${{formatprice|{{Inflation|US|497151.42|1929}}}} in {{Inflation-year|US}} dollars{{inflation-fn|US}}) | architect = Proudfoot, Rawson, and Souers{{cite book |last1=Turnbull|first1=Buck|title=Stadium Stories: Iowa Hawkeyes|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=HyHdYYhT6SgC&pg=PA48&dq=en&ei=wB96TrnsMIi3twe19-UL&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=2&ved=0CDkQ6AEwAQ#v=onepage&q=false|accessdate=|publisher=Morris Book Publishing, LLC.|location=Guilford, Connecticut|isbn=0-7627-3819-7|page=42}}
[[HNTB]] (renovation) | former_names = Iowa Stadium (1929–1972) | tenants = [[Iowa Hawkeyes football]] ([[National Collegiate Athletic Association|NCAA]]) (1929–present) | seating_capacity = 69,250 (2018–present){{cite news |title=Iowa AD Gary Barta Moves From 'No' to 'If' on Alcohol Sales in Kinnick Stadium|first=Marc|last=Morehouse|url=https://www.thegazette.com/subject/sports/barta-moves-from-no-to-if-on-alcohol-sales-in-kinnick-20180725|newspaper=[[The Gazette (Cedar Rapids)]]|date=July 25, 2018|accessdate=July 25, 2018}}
70,585 (2006–2017)
70,397 (1992–2005)
70,220 (1990–1991)
67,700 (1983–1989)
60,160 (1956–1982)
53,000 (1929–1955) }} '''Kinnick Stadium''', formerly known as '''Iowa Stadium''', is a [[stadium]] located in [[Iowa City, Iowa]], United States. It is the home stadium of the [[University of Iowa]] [[Iowa Hawkeyes football|Hawkeyes]], in the [[sport]] of [[college football]]. First opened in 1929 to replace [[Iowa Field]], it currently holds up to 69,250 people, making it the 7th largest stadium in the [[Big Ten]], and one of the 20 largest university owned stadiums in the nation. It is named for [[Nile Kinnick]], the 1939 [[Heisman Trophy]] winner and the only Heisman winner in university history, who died in service during [[World War II]]. It was named Iowa Stadium until 1972, when longtime lobbying by ''[[The Gazette (Cedar Rapids)|Cedar Rapids Gazette]]'' sportswriter Gus Schrader successfully convinced the UI athletic board to change the name. It is currently the only college football stadium named after a Heisman Trophy winner. ==Construction== Iowa Stadium was constructed in only seven months between 1928 and 1929. Groundbreaking and construction began on March 6, 1929. Workers worked around the clock using lights by night and horses and mules as the primary heavy-equipment movers. There was a rumor for many years that horses that died during the process were buried under what now is the North end zone.[http://iagenweb.org/johnson/Postcard80.htm IAGenWeb Project] {{dead link|date=June 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} Historians report this is a myth and the animals were disposed of in the nearby Iowa River. The round-the-clock construction came to an end in July. Despite several problems to overcome, including the [[athletic director]]'s resignation and a slight redesign, the stadium was completed and the first game was played October 5, 1929, against [[Monmouth College]]. Iowa won the game 46–0. The stadium was dedicated two weeks later, when the Hawkeyes tied [[1929 Illinois Fighting Illini football team|Illinois]] 7–7.{{cite web |title=Kinnick Stadium|url=http://football.ballparks.com/NCAA/Big10/Iowa/index.htm|work=Ballparks.com|year=2005|accessdate=July 25, 2007}} ==Features== The playing surface is currently the synthetic FieldTurf (installed in 2017), although it was [[AstroTurf]] from 1972 until grass was reinstalled for the 1989 season. The installation of artificial turf came at the same time that Iowa Stadium was renamed Kinnick Stadium in honor of the Heisman winner who had perished 29 years earlier. When filled to capacity, Kinnick Stadium would be the sixth largest city in Iowa (after [[Des Moines]], [[Cedar Rapids]], [[Davenport, Iowa|Davenport]], [[Sioux City]], and Iowa City).{{cite web|url=https://www.iowa-demographics.com/cities_by_population|title=Iowa Cities by Population|date=May 2018|work=Iowa-Demographics|accessdate=June 20, 2018}} Prior to the 2015 football season, the stadium did not have permanent lights; the school contracted Musco Lighting's portable light trucks for night games in previous years. The school had installed permanent practice lights at the stadium in 2012.{{cite news |title=Permanent Lights at Kinnick Stadium Could Mean More Evening Events|first=Mark|last=Carlson|url=http://www.thegazette.com/subject/sports/permanent-lights-at-kinnick-stadium-could-mean-more-evening-events-20150901|newspaper=[[The Gazette (Cedar Rapids)]]|date=September 1, 2015|accessdate=April 1, 2018}}{{cite web |title=Kinnick Stadium|url=http://hawkeyesports.com/sports/2016/6/13/facilities-iowa-kinnick-stadium-html.aspx|publisher=The University of Iowa Athletics|date=June 13, 2016|accessdate=April 1, 2018}}{{cite web |title=Iowa Football Practicing Around Construction|url=http://hawkeyesports.com/news/2012/4/2/iowa_football_practicing_around_construction.aspx|publisher=The University of Iowa Athletics|date=April 2, 2012|accessdate=April 1, 2018}} By capacity, Kinnick Stadium is the 27th largest college football stadium, the 42nd largest sports stadium in the United States, and the 86th largest sports stadium in the world. On November 14, 2015, Iowa set the national collegiate wrestling dual-meet attendance record at Kinnick with over 42,000 fans in a victory over #1 [[Oklahoma State Cowboys wrestling|Oklahoma State]]. [[File:Fall 2009 010.jpg|thumb|left|alt=Inside the visitor's pink locker room inside Kinnick Stadium. Former Iowa coach Hayden Fry had the locker room painted pink.|Inside the visitor's pink locker room inside Kinnick Stadium. Former Iowa coach Hayden Fry had the locker room painted pink.]] Kinnick Stadium is well known for its [[pink]] visitors' locker rooms, a tradition started by emeritus Iowa coach [[Hayden Fry]].{{cite news |title=Hayden Lives On: Visitors' Quarters Still Pretty in Pink|first=Sean|last=Keeler|url=https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/desmoinesregister/access/1785670031.html?FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&type=current&date=Aug+21%2C+2005&author=Keeler+Sean&pub=Des+Moines+Register&edition=&startpage=C.1&desc=Headline%3A+Hayden+lives+on%3A+Visitors%27+quarters+still+pretty+in+pink|newspaper=[[The Des Moines Register]]|date=August 21, 2005|accessdate=June 6, 2012}} Believing that pink would put opponents in a "passive mood", and because he thought that some believed pink was a "sissy color", Fry had the visiting locker rooms decorated completely in the color pink. {{quote box|quote=One thing we didn't paint black and gold was the stadium's visitors locker room, which we painted pink. It's a passive color, and we hoped it would put our opponents in a passive mood. Also, pink is often found in girls' bedrooms, and because of that some consider it a sissy color.|source=Hayden Fry, ''Hayden Fry: A High Porch Picnic'', p. 102{{cite book|last=Fry|first=Hayden|first2=George|last2=Wine|title=Hayden Fry: A High Porch Picnic|year=1999|publisher=Sports Publishing LLC|isbn=1-58261-033-9|page=102}}|width=75%|align=right}} The pink locker room tradition has been continued with the newly renovated locker rooms, which include everything from pink urinals to pink lockers. Controversy flared during the 2005 season when a visiting law professor, along with other university faculty and students protested the pink coloration as demeaning to women and homosexuals.{{cite news |title=Opponents Seeing Red Over Iowa's Pink Locker Room|url=http://www.msnbc.msn.com/id/9517000/|agency=[[Associated press]]|work=[[MSNBC]]|date=September 28, 2005}}{{cite web |title=Iowa Pink Visitors' Locker Room Under Fire|first=Christopher|last=Curtis|url=http://www.gay.com/news/article.html?2005/09/28/4|website=[[gay.com]]|date=September 28, 2005|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20060428054204/http://www.gay.com/news/article.html?2005/09/28/4|archivedate=April 28, 2006}}{{cite journal |last=Buzuvis|first=Erin|title=Reading The Pink Locker Room: On Football Culture And Title IX|journal=William & Mary Journal of Women and the Law|year=2007|volume=14|issue=1|pages=2|url=http://scholarship.law.wm.edu/wmjowl/vol14/iss1/2/}} Despite these protests and with lots of student support, however, the locker room remains pink. A more recent feature is the {{convert|20|ft|m|adj=mid|-tall}} bronze statue of [[Heisman Trophy]] winner [[Nile Kinnick]], the statue depicts Kinnick dressed as a scholar, rather than in his football uniform. The bronze statue is placed near the team entrance to the stadium. When the renovation of the stadium was completed, and the statue unveiled, a tradition among the players began: one player, before entering the locker room, reached out and touched the helmet that was placed at Kinnick's feet. From that point on, all Iowa players, before entering the locker room, and after getting off the bus, walk up to the statue and rub the helmet, as a token of respect for Kinnick - the only Iowa player to ever win the Heisman Trophy. The on-field entrances to the stadium all have one thing in common, a picture of Nile Kinnick is placed above the tunnel before exiting the tunnel to the field. ==Renovation== [[File:New Kinnick scoreboard.jpg|thumb|right|140px|The new scoreboard in the south end zone at Kinnick Stadium.]] After 75 years of operation, the [[Board of Regents, State of Iowa|Iowa Board of Regents]] endorsed a major renovation of Kinnick Stadium on March 10, 2004. The US$86.8 million project was to build a new state of the art press box, a new scoreboard with a new sound system, replace the "temporary" south endzone bleachers with permanent seating, triple the restroom facilities, and more than double the number of concession stands, as well as smaller changes such as new locker rooms, a bronze statue of [[Nile Kinnick]] and the dedication of the Krause Family Plaza to which Kinnick Stadium is now adjacent. Every brick for the renovation came from the Glen-Gery Brickyard in [[Redfield, Iowa]], which is located near Nile Kinnick's childhood home in [[Adel, Iowa]].{{cite book |title=Iowa Hawkeyes Roost in Historic Rebuilt Stadium|url=http://www.gass.com/colleen/CI_Update/CI_summer06_ebook.pdf|year=2006}} The stadium was rededicated on September 1, 2006. Among other things, the rededication featured a [[flypast|flyover]] by a [[F4F Wildcat]], the aircraft that Kinnick flew in [[World War II]].{{cite news |title=Kinnick Set to Reopen|first=Ian|last=Smith|url=http://media.www.dailyiowan.com/media/storage/paper599/news/2006/08/30/Sports/Kinnick.Set.To.Reopen-2251240.shtml?sourcedomain=www.dailyiowan.com&MIIHost=media.collegepublisher.com|newspaper=[[The Daily Iowan]]|date=August 30, 2006|accessdate=March 5, 2008|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080305040221/http://media.www.dailyiowan.com/media/storage/paper599/news/2006/08/30/Sports/Kinnick.Set.To.Reopen-2251240.shtml?sourcedomain=www.dailyiowan.com&MIIHost=media.collegepublisher.com|archivedate=March 5, 2008}} The stadium also underwent major renovations in 1956, 1983, and 1990 where capacity was gradually taken from 53,000 to 70,397. The 2004–06 renovations pushed the capacity to 70,585. In the spring of 2009, the natural grass turf and 20-year-old drainage system were replaced with a new state-of-the-art synthetic [[FieldTurf]] playing surface. In 2013, the Iowa Board of Regents approved an $8 million upgrade of Kinnick Stadium's video and sound systems. These upgrades include the installation of new HD video displays in both the north and south endzones, as well as a new HD ribbon display above the north endzone.{{cite news |title=Regents Approve Kinnick Video, Sound Upgrade|first=Marc|last=Morehouse|url=http://thegazette.com/2013/04/25/regents-approve-kinnick-video-sound-upgrade/|newspaper=[[The Gazette (Cedar Rapids)]]|date=April 25, 2013|accessdate=April 1, 2018}} The upgrades were completed by the start of the 2013 football season. In 2016, the Iowa Board of Regents approved an $89.9 million upgrade to Kinnick Stadium's north end zone. The proposed renovation features the addition of box seating, outdoor club seating and a scoreboard larger than the board in the south end zone. All seating will be ready for the 2018 football season while the rest of the project is scheduled to be completed by the start of the 2019 football season.{{cite web |title=UI Receives Approval for Kinnick Stadium Renovation|url=http://www.hawkeyesports.com/news/2016/10/20/football-ui-receives-approval-for-kinnick-stadium-renovation.aspx|publisher=The University of Iowa Athletics|date=October 20, 2016|accessdate=October 31, 2016}} [[File:Iowa Football Practice Facility.jpg|thumb|The indoor practice facility under construction near Kinnick Stadium.]] [[File:IANR 678 ROCK.jpg|thumb|IANR 678 ROCK|The Hawkeye Express train transports spectators to Kinnick Stadium from Coralville on game day.]] ==The Children's Hospital and the Wave== The [[University of Iowa Children's Hospital]]'s new building overlooks the Kinnick Stadium. The opening of the new hospital in 2017 led to the creation of what [[ESPN]] called "[[college football]]'s coolest new tradition." The new facility includes a top-floor lounge area known as the Press Box Cafe that has a view of the entire field, allowing patients and their families to see all Iowa home games live, and also includes big-screen TVs to allow them to watch Hawkeyes road games. A suggestion on a Hawkeyes fan page on [[Facebook]] led to "The Wave"—at the end of the first quarter of Iowa home games, the crowd faces the hospital and waves at the patients and their families watching in the Press Box.{{cite web|url=http://www.espn.com/college-football/story/_/id/20744480/iowa-hawkeyes-hospital-wave |title=Inside college football's coolest new tradition: Iowa's hospital wave |first=Mitch |last=Sherman |publisher=''[[ESPN.com]]'' |date=September 18, 2017 |accessdate=September 23, 2017}} For the Hawkeyes' first night home game of the [[2017 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|2017 season]] against [[2017 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]], the fan site where the idea of "The Wave" originated encouraged fans to turn on their cell phone flashlights while they waved to the patients.{{cite news|url=http://www.kcrg.com/content/news/Meet-the-woman-who-helped-make-The-Wave-happen-446953363.html |title=Meet the woman who helped make 'The Wave' happen |first=Forrest |last=Saunders |publisher=[[KCRG-TV]] |location=Cedar Rapids, Iowa |date=September 22, 2017 |accessdate=September 23, 2017}} == "Kinnick Voodoo" == Since 2008, Iowa is 4-1 against AP Top 5 opponents in Kinnick Stadium. In 2008, an unranked Iowa beat 3rd ranked [[2008 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State]] on kicker Daniel Murray’s walk off field goal. The game-winning field goal capped a stunning Iowa comeback in a game that Penn State led 23-14 with 9:21 remaining in the 4th quarter. In 2010, 5th ranked [[2010 Michigan State Spartans football team|Michigan State]] visited Kinnick Stadium looking to continue their undefeated season. The 18th ranked Hawkeyes would beat the Spartans by a final score of 37-6, in a game that Iowa led 30-0 at halftime. The Spartans would not put any points on the scoreboard until the 4th quarter. In 2015, fans in Kinnick Stadium got to witness Iowa's most successful regular season in school history. The [[2015 Iowa Hawkeyes football team|Hawkeyes]] went 12-0 and won the Big Ten West Division. After a heartbreaking loss in the [[2015 Big Ten Football Championship Game|Big Ten Championship Game]] to [[2015 Michigan State Spartans football team|Michigan State]], the Hawkeyes received a bid to the [[2016 Rose Bowl|Rose Bowl]], its first [[College Football Playoff New Year's Six|New Year's Six bowl]] invitation since the start of the College Football Playoff system. In 2016, 3rd ranked [[2016 Michigan Wolverines football team|Michigan]] was knocked off by an unranked Iowa by a score of 14-13, with kicker Keith Duncan’s walk off game-winning field goal. The game was televised on [[ABC Saturday Night Football]]. In 2017, an unranked and 20 point underdog Iowa knocked off the 3rd ranked [[2017 Ohio State Buckeyes football team|Ohio State Buckeyes]] by a score of 55-24. Earlier in 2017, it took a touchdown on 4th down on the last play of the game for the 3rd ranked [[2017 Penn State Nittany Lions football team|Penn State Nittany Lions]] to beat the unranked Hawkeyes 21-19. The game was televised on [[ABC Saturday Night Football]]. ==Gallery== Image:KinnickNDrelief.jpg | Relief of [[Nile Kinnick| Nile Kinnick's]] famous touchdown against the [[1939 Notre Dame Fighting Irish football team|University of Notre Dame]] in south end of the stadium. Image:Kinnick Night.jpg | Kinnick Stadium during a September 7, 2007, game against [[2007 Syracuse Orange football team|Syracuse University]] Image:DSCN0602.JPG|Students rushing renovated Kinnick Stadium following the Iowa-Iowa State game, September 16, 2006 ==See also== * [[List of NCAA Division I FBS football stadiums]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== * [http://www.hawkeyesports.com/facilities/iowa-kinnick-stadium.html Historic Kinnick Stadium] at HawkeyeSports.com * [http://maps.uiowa.edu/ks Map of the Historic Kinnick Stadium area] {{Iowa Hawkeyes football navbox}} {{University of Iowa|athletics}} {{Big Ten Conference football venue navbox}} {{Iowa Pre-Flight Seahawks football navbox}} {{Iowa college football venues}} [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:Iowa Hawkeyes football]] [[Category:Iowa Pre-Flight Seahawks football]] [[Category:University of Iowa campus]] [[Category:American football venues in Iowa]] [[Category:1929 establishments in Iowa]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1929]]

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Laugardalshöll | image = Ísland - Frakkland Laugardalshöll, 16. & 17. apríl 2010 (4539188772).jpg | location = [[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]] | coordinates = {{coord|64.140305|N|21.877985|W|type:landmark_scale:2000|display=inline,title}} | seating_capacity = Sports: 5,500
Concerts: 11,000 | broke_ground = | opened = 6 December 1965 | owner = | operator = Sports and Exhibition Center (ÍSH) | architect = Gísli Halldórsson
Skarphéðinn Jóhannesson{{cite web|url=https://grapevine.is/news/2017/03/27/reykjavik-of-yore-laugardalshollin/|title=Reykjavík of Yore: Laugardalshöllin - The Reykjavik Grapevine|website=grapevine.is|date=27 March 2017|publisher=|accessdate=18 March 2018}} | tenants = [[Iceland men's national basketball team|Icelandic men's national basketball team]]
[[Iceland women's national basketball team|Icelandic women's national basketball team]]
[[Iceland men's national handball team|Icelandic men's national handball team]]
[[Iceland women's national handball team|Icelandic women's national handball team]] }} '''Laugardalshöll''' is an [[indoor arena|indoor sporting arena]] located in [[Reykjavík]], [[Iceland]]. The capacity of the arena is 5,500 people. It hosts various sporting events, such as handball, basketball, volleyball and athletics, as well as for other events. Aside from sporting events, it is the largest concert venue in Iceland, with a maximum capacity of 11,000. Aside from sports and music events, it serves as a general purpose hall for all manner of events. ==Events== Perhaps the most prominent event to be held at Laugardalshöll was the [[World Chess Championship 1972]], often dubbed the "Match of the Century", in which [[United States of America|America]]n challenger [[Bobby Fischer]] defeated the [[Russia]] champion [[Boris Spassky]]. The movie ''[[Bobby Fischer Against the World]]'' (2011) features scenes from Laugardalshöll.Conolly, Jez and Caroline Whelan. ''World Film Locations: Reykjavik''. Intellect Books. Page 100. {{ISBN|9781841506418}}. The arena which hosted the [[1995 World Men's Handball Championship]] and many matches of the [[Iceland national handball team]], one of the most successful sports of the country. On November 6, 2010, the "National Assembly", the first step of a constitutional reform process, was held here. It gathered 1000 citizens, randomly picked in the national register. It produced a document listing the main principles of the island nation. From 2007 to 2011, it also hosted [[CCP Games]]' [[EVE Online]] annual 'Fanfest'. Every year since 2016, the arena has held the finals of [[Söngvakeppnin]], the Icelandic preliminary round for the [[Eurovision Song Contest]]. ==References== ==External links== *{{Official website|http://www.laugardalsholl.is/}} {{is icon}} {{s-start}} {{succession box | | title=[[World Men's Handball Championship]]
Final Venue | before=[[Globe Arena]]
[[Stockholm]] | after=[[Park Dome Kumamoto|Park Dome]]
[[Kumamoto]] | years='''[[1995 World Men's Handball Championship|1995]]''' }} {{s-end}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Laugardalsholl}} [[Category:Handball venues]] [[Category:Indoor arenas in Iceland]] [[Category:Sports venues in Reykjavík]] [[Category:Basketball venues in Iceland]] [[Category:Volleyball venues in Iceland]] {{Iceland-sports-venue-stub}}

revision.comment: Corrected an error. In 1995-96, the Red Wings did not break the record for most points in a season by a team.
revision.text:
[[File:Ice_Hockey_Left_Wing_Lock.gif|thumb|250px|In this diagram, the red team is executing a left wing lock.]]The '''left wing lock''' is a defensive [[ice hockey]] strategy similar to the [[neutral zone trap]].
In the most basic form, once puck possession changes, the [[Winger (ice hockey)|left wing]] moves back in line with the [[Defenceman (ice hockey)|defencemen]]. Each defender (including the left winger) plays a [[zone defence]] and is responsible for a third of the ice each.{{sfn|Raimondo|2007}} Since there are normally only two defencemen, this [[Ice hockey#Tactics|tactic]] helps to avoid [[odd man rush]]es.
With the reinforced defensive line, the [[Centre (ice hockey)|centre]] and [[Winger (hockey)|right wing]] [[forecheck]] aggressively. Often the forecheckers will try to drive the puck over to the opponent's right wing.
Under coach [[Scotty Bowman]], the [[Detroit Red Wings]] began using "the lock" heavily during the [[1994-95 NHL season]], earning the [[President's Trophy]] for the league's best record during the regular season. The following season Detroit was even more dominant, finishing one point short of the [[NHL]] record for most points in a season by a team. However, the system broke down during the playoffs each year, especially as they were frustrated by the neutral zone trap strategy employed by [[Jacques Lemaire]]'s [[New Jersey Devils]] in the [[1995 Stanley Cup Finals]]. It was not until 1997 that Detroit broke through and finally matched their regular-season success with a [[Stanley Cup]] championship.
Although "the lock" was made famous by the Red Wings and has been used to great success in their [[Stanley Cup]] runs in the past decade, they are not credited with inventing it. The "lock" was invented in [[Czechoslovakia]] to work against the dominant [[Soviet Union|Soviet]] [[Soviet Union national ice hockey team|teams]] of the 1970s.{{sfn|Raimondo|2007}} A former assistant coach under Scotty Bowman, [[Barry Smith (ice hockey, born 1952)|Barry Smith]], was credited with seeing the left wing lock in [[Europe]] and bringing it back to the Red Wings.<ref>[http://slapshot.blogs.nytimes.com/tag/barry-smith/ Barry Smith - Slap Shot Blog], ''[[New York Times]]''</ref>
The simplicity of "the lock" has made it popular at all levels of hockey and it is not uncommon to see it implemented in [[youth hockey]].
==References== ;Notes {{reflist}}
* {{cite web |url=http://www.hockeyplayer.com/paid/publish/article_549.shtml |title=The Left Wing Lock |last=Raimondo |first=Gianni |year=2007 |ref=harv}}
{{DEFAULTSORT:Left Wing Lock}} [[Category:Ice hockey terminology]] [[Category:Ice hockey strategy]]

revision.text:
{{EngvarB|date=September 2013}} {{Use dmy dates|date=September 2013}} {{Infobox cricket ground | ground_name = Macclesfield Cricket Club Ground | nickname = | country = England | image = Macclesfield Cricket Club (3).JPG | location = [[Macclesfield]], Cheshire | establishment = 1920 (first recorded match) | coord = {{coord|53.2625|-2.1457|type:landmark_region:GB|display=inline,title}} | seating_capacity = | end1 = | end2 = | year1 = 1974 | club1 = [[Minor Counties North]] | year2 = 1920–1984 | club2 = [[Cheshire County Cricket Club|Cheshire]] | date = 10 July | year = 2012 | source = http://www.espncricinfo.com/england/content/ground/57674.html Ground profile }}
'''Macclesfield Cricket Club Ground''' is a [[cricket]] ground in Victoria Road, [[Macclesfield]], Cheshire. A small ground,<ref name="NEWS">{{cite news|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/macclesfieldexpress/news/s/394950_cricket_club_defends_its_land_swap_deal|title=Cricket club defends its land swap deal|last=Taylor|first=Paul|date=7 August 2003|work=[[Macclesfield Express]]|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> it is bordered to the east by [[Macclesfield District Hospital]] and to the south and west by housing. The ground is used by [[Macclesfield Cricket Club]]. [[Field hockey]] and [[lawn bowls]] are also played at the ground.
==History== Macclesfield Cricket Club has been in existence for over 180 years, though where the club originally played is unknown. The first recorded match on the current ground came in [[Cheshire County Cricket Club|Cheshire's]] first match there in the 1921 [[Minor Counties Championship]] against [[Staffordshire County Cricket Club|Staffordshire]].<ref name="MCM">{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/613_minc.html|title=Minor Counties Championship Matches played on Macclesfield Cricket Club Ground|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> Cheshire played an annual Minor Counties Championship at the ground until 1931.<ref name="MCM"/> [[Minor counties of English and Welsh cricket|Minor counties]] cricket did not return to the ground until 1949, when Cheshire played the [[Worcestershire County Cricket Club|Worcestershire Second XI]] in the Minor Counties Championship. Cheshire played annually at the ground throughout the 1950s and 1960s. It was in the [[1966 Gillette Cup]] that the ground held its first [[List A cricket|List A]] match when Cheshire played [[first-class cricket|first-class]] opponents in the form of [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]].<ref name="LAM">{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/613_a.html|title=List A Matches played on Macclesfield Cricket Club Ground|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> Two further List A matches were held there in the [[1968 Gillette Cup]], with Cheshire defeating [[Norfolk County Cricket Club|Norfolk]] in a first round match, but losing to [[Northamptonshire County Cricket Club|Northamptonshire]] in the second round.<ref name="LAM"/> A final List A match was held there in 1974, when the ground was selected as a home venue for [[Minor Counties North]] in the [[1974 Benson & Hedges Cup|Benson & Hedges Cup]], with Lancashire as the visitors.<ref name="LAM"/> The ground continued to host Minor Counties Championship matches during the 1970s, with the final Minor Counties Championship match held in 1982.<ref name="MCM"/> In 1983, the ground held the first final of the [[MCCA Knockout Trophy]], which saw Cheshire triumph over [[Bedfordshire County Cricket Club|Bedfordshire]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/44/44063.html|title=Cheshire v Bedfordshire, 1983 MCCA Kockout Trophy|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> A second MCCA Knockout Trophy match was held in 1984, with [[Hertfordshire County Cricket Club|Hertfordshire]] as the visitors.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/613_mint.html|title=Minor Counties Trophy Matches played on Macclesfield Cricket Club Ground|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> This was the last time the ground was used by Cheshire.
In latter years the ground has had to contend with deteriorating facilities. In 2003, plans were drawn up for Macclesfield Cricket Club to sell the ground for development and move to a new ground along London Road.<ref name="NEWS"/> However these plans failed to come to fruition.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/macclesfieldexpress/news/s/405810_cricket_ground_plan_rejected_by_inspector|title=Cricket ground plan rejected by inspector|date=6 October 2004|work=[[Macclesfield Express]]|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> In 2011, plans were drawn up to transform the ground into one of the leading leisure facilities in Cheshire, with the undertaking of an £800,000 redevelopment project.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://menmedia.co.uk/macclesfieldexpress/news/s/1408295_video_cricket_club_sets_out_new_vision|title=Cricket club sets out new vision|last=Slater|first=Chris|date=16 February 2011|work=[[Macclesfield Express]]|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref>
==Records==
===List A=== * '''Highest team total:''' 212/9 (59.4 overs) by [[Cheshire County Cricket Club|Cheshire]] v [[Norfolk County Cricket Club|Norfolk]], 1968<ref name="NOR">{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/29/29349.html|title=Cheshire v Norfolk, 1968 Gillette Cup|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> * '''Lowest team total:''' 62 all out (45.3 overs) by Cheshire v [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]], 1966<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/613/a_Lowest_Team_Totals.html|title=Macclesfield Cricket Club Ground – Lowest Team Totals in List A matches|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref> * '''Highest individual innings:''' 73 by [[Graham Saville]] for Norfolk v Cheshire, 1968<ref name="NOR"/> * '''Best bowling in an innings:''' 4/10 by [[Ken Higgs]] for [[Lancashire County Cricket Club|Lancashire]] v Cheshire, 1966<ref>{{cite web|url=https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Scorecards/27/27989.html|title=Cheshire v Lancashire, 1966 Gillette Cup|publisher=CricketArchive|accessdate=10 July 2012}}</ref>
==Gallery== <gallery class="center"> File:Macclesfield Cricket Club (2).JPG|<center>View of the [[cricket pavilion|pavilion]].</center> File:Macclesfield Cricket Club (5).JPG|<center>Wider view of the ground.</center> File:Macclesfield Cricket Club (18).JPG|<center>View of the ground toward the pavilion.</center> File:Macclesfield Cricket Club (7).JPG|<center>View of the scorers hut.</center> File:Macclesfield Cricket Club (23).JPG|<center>Welcome sign at the ground.</center> </gallery>
==See also== *[[List of cricket grounds in England and Wales]]
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== {{Commons category|Macclesfield Cricket Club}} *[https://cricketarchive.com/Archive/Grounds/11/613.html Macclesfield Cricket Club Ground] at CricketArchive *[http://www.cricinfo.com/england/content/ground/57674.html Macclesfield Cricket Club Ground] at [[ESPNcricinfo]]

{{Infobox casino | name = Mohegan Sun Pocono | logo = | logo_size = | logo_alt = | logo_caption = | image = Mohegan Poconos casino LuzCo PA.jpg | image_size = | image_alt = | image_caption = Mohegan Sun Pocono Entrance | pushpin_map = Pennsylvania#USA | pushpin_mapsize = | pushpin_map_alt = | pushpin_map_caption = Mohegan Sun Pocono in Pennsylvania | pushpin_label_position = | coordinates = | location = [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania|Wilkes-Barre]], [[Pennsylvania|PA]] | address = 1280 Hwy 315 | date_opened = | date_closed = | theme = | rooms = 238 | space_gaming = {{convert|82000|sqft}} | shows = | attractions = The Downs At Mohegan Sun Pocono | notable_restaurants = Ruth's Chris Steak House | casino_type = Land-based
[[Native American gaming]]
[[Racino]] | owner = '''Downs Racing, LP'''
Division of Mohegan Tribal Gaming Authority, of The [[Mohegan Tribe]] | license_holder = | architect = | names_pre = Pocono Downs
Mohegan Sun at Pocono Downs | renovations = | website = [http://mohegansunpocono.com/ Mohegan Sun Pocono] | footnotes = | embedded = }} '''Mohegan Sun Pocono''' (formerly '''Pocono Downs''' and '''Mohegan Sun at Pocono Downs''') is a [[racino]] located in [[Plains Township, Luzerne County, Pennsylvania|Plains Township]] on the outskirts of [[Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania]]. The casino features over 2,300 [[slot machine|slots]], and live tables for [[blackjack]], [[roulette]] and [[poker]]. A ⅝-mile (1-kilometer) [[harness racing|harness track]] is also a major attraction. ==History== The racetrack itself is as of 2015 now called The Downs At Mohegan Sun Pocono. [[Mohegan Sun]] acquired the Pocono Downs racetrack on January 25, 2005 in a $280 million purchase of the Pocono Downs Racetrack from [[Penn National Gaming]].Mohegan Sun Reports Mixed Results [http://www.casinocitytimes.com/news/article/mohegan-sun-reports-mixed-results-150362 "Mohegan Sun Reports Mixed Results"], ''Casino City Times'', Retrieved on 22 November 2007 Mohegan Sun renamed the property "Mohegan Sun at Pocono Downs," and began a major expansion. It began operation in November 2006 as the first slots casino in the state of Pennsylvania. In January 2010, [[Ed Rendell|then Governor Ed Rendell]] signed a bill to legalize [[table game]]s in Pennsylvania. The Mohegan Sun casino was among the first to receive approval for table games, and planned to hire 600 new employees for the expansion. Table games began operation on July 13, 2010. In November 2013, Mohegan Sun opened a hotel that is connected to the casino floor. ==Features== ===Dining and shopping=== The facility has fourteen restaurants or food service areas, including a food court, [[Ben & Jerry's]], [[Johnny Rockets]], [[Ruth's Chris Steak House]], and [[Wolfgang Puck]] Express. There are also four shops, including a wine and cheese shop. ===Off-track wagering=== Mohegan Sun also owns off-track betting facilities in [[Carbondale, Pennsylvania|Carbondale]], [[East Stroudsburg, Pennsylvania|East Stroudsburg]], and [[Allentown, Pennsylvania|Allentown]]. ==Gallery== File:Mohegan Poconos hotelLuzCo PA.jpg| File:Mohegan Poconos torch LuzCo PA.jpg|Torch near the entrance ==See also== *[[List of casinos in Pennsylvania]] *[[List of casinos in the United States]] *[[List of casino hotels]] ==References== ==External links== *[http://mohegansunpocono.com/ Official Site] *[https://web.archive.org/web/20110207223912/http://downsotw.com/ Off Track Wagering site] {{coord|41.2689|-75.8193|region:US-PA_type:landmark|display=title}} {{Pennsylvania casinos}} {{Wilkes-Barre, Pennsylvania}} [[Category:Casinos in Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1965]] [[Category:Casinos completed in 2006]] [[Category:Buildings and structures in Luzerne County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Tourist attractions in Luzerne County, Pennsylvania]] [[Category:Horse racing venues in the United States]] [[Category:1965 establishments in Pennsylvania]]

{{Use dmy dates|date=March 2018}} {{Use Indian English|date=March 2018}} {{Infobox college |name = Netaji Subhas National Institute of Sports |native_name = |image_name = MotiBaghPalace.jpg |image_size = 200px |motto = |mottoeng = |established = 7 May 1961 |founder = |former_name = |address = |city = [[Patiala]] |state = |country = [[India]] |postcode = |coor = |students = |undergrad = |postgrad = |campus = |parent = [[Sports Authority of India]] |academic_affiliation = [[Maharaja Bhupinder Singh Sports University]], [[Baba Farid University of Health Sciences]], [[Punjabi University]] |type = [[Government Degree Colleges, India|Government College]] |principal = |website = {{url|www.nsnis.org}} }}
'''Netaji Subhas National Institute of Sports''' commonly known as '''National Institute of Sports''' (NIS), is the Academic Wing of the [[Sports Authority of India]] (SAI) and Asia's largest Sports Institute located in city of [[Patiala]].
== History == Founded in 7 May 1961, the Institute was renamed as Netaji Subhas National Institute of Sports in January 1973. It is merged with SAI in 1987.<ref name=abt/> Spread over 268 acres, NIS is housed in the Old [[Moti Bagh Palace]] of the erstwhile royal family of [[Patiala State]], which was purchased by [[Government of India]] after [[Independence of India|Indian Independence]].<ref name=abt>{{cite web | title = About us | url = http://www.nsnis.org/about.htm|publisher=National Institute of Sports | accessdate = 2014-08-13 }}</ref>
== Memorabilia == Today, several items of sports memorabilia, like a hass (doughnut-shaped exercise disc), weighing 95 kg, used by [[The Great Gama]], for squats, and Major [[Dhyan Chand]]'s gold medal from the 1928 Amsterdam Olympics, and [[PT Usha]] 1986 Seoul Asiad shoes, are housed at the National Institute of Sports Museum.<ref>[http://www.tribuneindia.com/2001/20011124/windows/main5.htm A rare museum], ''[[The Tribune (Chandigarh)]]'', 24 November 2001.</ref>
== Departments == # Department of [[Sports Medicine]] # Department of [[Exercise Physiology]] # Department of Sports [[Biochemistry]] # Department of Sports [[Anthropometry]] # Department of [[Sports Psychology]] # Department of Sports [[Nutrition]] # Department of General Theory & Methods of Training # Department of [[Biomechanics]]
==Sports facilities== * [[Gym]]nasium and [[swimming pool]] complex * Three indoor halls for [[wrestling]], [[Olympic weightlifting|weightlifting]], [[boxing]], [[basketball]], [[badminton]], [[table tennis]] * [[Volleyball]], [[Team handball|handball]] and [[judo]] * Two [[Squash (sport)|squash]] courts * [[Cycling]] velodrome * [[Hockey]] field astroturf and three grass fields * [[Athletics (sport)|Athletic]] track - synthetic (8 lanes), grass (4 lanes) and cinder (8 lanes) * Area for throws * Two [[basketball]] cement courts * Two [[Association football|football]] grounds * Two [[Team handball|handball]] grounds * [[Tennis]] (3 hard and 3 grass courts) * Four [[volleyball]] courts * Turf wicket [[cricket]] ground and 6 cricket nets * [[Archery]] ground * Nine-hole [[golf]] course * Five-lane [[jogging]] and cross country track * [[Wushu (sport)|Wushu]] Training Centre * [[Fencing]] training centre
==References== {{Reflist}}<!--added above External links/Sources by script-assisted edit-->
http://nsnis.org/about-nsnis-patiala/

Left Center Field: 355 ft.

Right Center Field:345 ft.
Right Field Line: 295 ft.}} '''QU Stadium''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Quincy, Illinois]] originally known as Q Stadium.{{cite web|url=http://www.quincygems.com/view/quincygems/gems-history|title=Q-Stadium|publisher=quincygems.com|accessdate=2018-04-24}} It is primarily used for [[baseball]], but also has a separate [[American football|football]] field.{{cite web|url=https://quhawks.com/sports/2010/12/27/BB_1227101701.aspx?path=baseball|title=QU Stadium-Baseball|publisher=quhawks.com|accessdate=2018-04-24}} The baseball side and football side of QU Stadium holds 2,500 people. The football side of the stadium (located beyond the right and right center field fence of the baseball field) only has bleachers on one side of the field.{{cite web|url=https://quhawks.com/sports/2010/12/27/FB_1227101536.aspx|title=QU Stadium-Football|publisher=quhawks.com|accessdate=2018-04-24}} The stadium is surrounded by its original limestone wall built in 1938. ==History== The stadium was built in 1938 as part of the [[Works Progress Administration|WPA]] and originally owned by the City of Quincy. It is constructed of large limestone blocks and concrete. A "sister" facility of limestone and concrete was built near Quincy High School (which was then located at 13th & Maine). This sister facility was the practice field for Quincy High School athletic teams until a new high school was built at 30th & Maine. At that time, the building at 13th & Maine became Quincy Junior High School and the athletic fields continued to be used by QJHS athletic teams. In 1984, the city sold the stadium to Quincy College (later [[Quincy University]]), a local liberal-arts 4-year Roman Catholic college affiliated with the Order of Friars Minor (Franciscans). The name of the stadium was changed to QC stadium and then to QU stadium, after Quincy College changed its name to Quincy University. ===Baseball history=== The stadium has been home to the [[Quincy Gems (baseball)|Quincy Gems baseball]] of the [[Illinois–Indiana–Iowa League|Three-I League]] from 1946 to 1956.{{cite web|url=https://www.baseball-reference.com/bullpen/Q_Stadium|title=Q Stadium|publisher=baseball-reference.com|accessdate=2018-04-24}} From 1960 to 1961 the [[Quincy Giants]] of the [[Midwest League]] (ML) played there. During the 1962 and 1963 seasons the [[Quincy Jets]] ([[Midwest League|ML]]), a [[New York Mets]] farm team, played their home games at the stadium and in 1964 another [[Quincy Gems (baseball)|Quincy Gems baseball]] team played at the stadium. From 1965 to 1973, the [[Quincy Cubs]], a [[Chicago Cubs]] farm team in the [[Midwest League]] called Q Stadium home. The Quincy Rivermen of the [[Central Illinois Collegiate League]] (CICL) played at the stadium from 1974 to 1987. Since 1995, it has been the home of [[Quincy Hawks|Quincy University Hawks]] baseball team. In 1996, the [[Quincy Gems]] of both the CICL and [[Prospect League]] have played at the stadium.{{cite web|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091027122011/http://www.geocities.com/shoeless1920/Quincy.html|title=Q Stadium – Quincy, Illinois|publisher=geocities.com|accessdate=2018-04-24}} ===Football history=== The stadium was originally used for football by [[Quincy Senior High School]] and [[Quincy Notre Dame High School]] as their home football field until a new stadium was completed in 1980 (Flinn Stadium). Both schools, as well as Quincy College (later [[Quincy University]]), used the baseball side of the stadium for football. After both high schools quit using the stadium for football, the Quincy YMCA Tackle Football League began using the football side for the 7th & 8th grade league. The YMCA also used the field for two youth flag football leagues – a 2nd through 4th grade league, and a 5th & 6th grade league. The Quincy Family YMCA completed a field on its property, so the tackle football and flag football leagues moved to that field in 1984. In 1987, then [[Quincy University|Quincy College]] re-instated its football program after an over 30 year hiatus. The Hawks began using the football side of QC Stadium competing in NCAA Division III. The Hawks moved up to NCAA Division II during the 1990s. In 2010, the football team moved to Flinn Stadium, but moved back to QU Stadium in 2014 after a major renovation. ==References== {{Reflist}} == External links == * [https://web.archive.org/web/20091027122011/http://www.geocities.com/shoeless1920/Quincy.html QU Stadium Website] {{Illinois college football venues}} {{Prospect League Ballparks|state=autocollapse}} {{DEFAULTSORT:Qu Stadium}} [[Category:American football venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Baseball venues in Illinois]] [[Category:Minor league baseball venues]] [[Category:Midwest League ballparks]] [[Category:Quincy Hawks baseball]] [[Category:Quincy Hawks football]] [[Category:Sports venues in Quincy, Illinois]] [[Category:1938 establishments in Illinois]] [[Category:College football venues]] [[Category:College baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1938]]

The team won Twelve China League champion titles. The team with the name and different extensions have been present as, Shanghai Tang Dynasty and Fudan University Shanghai and now Shanghai Golden Age. Shanghai Volleyball Club have been a dominant force in the Chinese League since its inauguration in 1997, having won 14 titles in 22 editions to date – including the last four consecutive editions. ''Sleeping Bag Liners'' are lightweight cloth sacks usually fitted inside [[sleeping bag]]s to provide extra comfort, insulation, and help keep the sleeping bag clean.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/extras/indybest/outdoor-activity/5-best-sleeping-bag-liners-10082198.html|title=''5 best sleeping bag liners'' - independent.co.uk}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.dofeshopping.org/expedition-kit/sleeping-bags-and-mats|title=Advice on Sleeping Bag Liners from The Duke of Edinburgh's Award}}</ref>
A thin bag liner may feel softer against the sleeper's skin, add 5 F warmth to the bag (not pad), and be easily washed after use (unlike the thicker sleeping bag). A thick, fleece-like liner can increase warmth by 10-15 F. Liners also allow a sleeper to use the liner alone, without the bag in hot conditions.<ref>https://www.rei.com/learn/expert-advice/sleeping-bag-liners.html</ref><ref>https://www.theadventurejunkies.com/best-sleeping-bag-liner/</ref> Optionally, bug-repellents, pockets, and a pillow holder can be added to liners.
A [[vapor barrier]] liner (VBL) is special type of liner that blocks the sleeper's moisture from reaching the bag, thus stopping [[Heat transfer#Evaporative cooling|evaporative]] heat loss. Usually a sleeping bag liner is used inside a VBL.
''Bag Liners'' are issued as basic kit by various militaries including the [[United States Armed Forces|US]] and [[British Armed Forces|British]] armed forces.<ref>{{Cite web|url=http://www.army.mod.uk/documents/general/Black_Bag_A5_booklet.pdf|title=Clothing for Operations "The Black Bag" - Ministry of Defense}}</ref>
== Fabrics ==
''Liners'' are made of [[silk]], [[cotton]], [[nylon]] and [[polyester]] among others.
Silk liners are light, soft and strong and retain much thermal insulation even when wet.
Cotton is heavier and bulkier than silk and absorbs water.
Synthetic [mix] liners are usually light, strong, and do not absorb water.
== See also == * [[Sleeping bag]] * [[Mosquito net]] * [[Bivouac sack]]
== References == {{Commons category|Sleeping bags}} {{reflist}} {{SleepSeries2}}

'''Southgate Cricket Club''' is located in the [[London]] suburb of [[Southgate, London|Southgate]]. The club played eight matches ranked as [[first-class cricket|first-class]] between 1863 and 1868. Six of these were against [[Oxford University Cricket Club|Oxford University]] and the remaining two were against [[Cambridge University Cricket Club|Cambridge University]]. Though recognised as first-class fixtures, they were all scheduled for only two days.<ref>[https://cricketarchive.com CricketArchive scorecard oracle - search on team name of "Southgate"].</ref> All of them were away fixtures.
== Club history == The club was founded in 1855 by the Walker brothers, the famous [[The Walkers of Southgate|"Walkers of Southgate"]]. Its ground, Chapel Fields in Waterfall Road, Southgate, was renamed the [[John Walker's Ground|Walker Cricket Ground]] in their honour in 1907 and is maintained by the Walker Trust to this day.<ref>[http://content-uk.cricinfo.com/england/content/ground/57319.html Cricinfo: "The Walker Cricket Ground, Southgate"]</ref><ref>[http://www.thewalkerground.co.uk Walker Trust website]</ref>
Four of the Walker brothers played for the [[United All-England Eleven]]. Both the United All-England team and the [[Marylebone Cricket Club|MCC]] would visit Southgate to take on the brothers and their team, attracting crowds of up to 10,000.
More recently Southgate CC won the national club cricket competition in 1977 (then called the John Haig Trophy) and the Middlesex County Cricket League in 1976 and 1977.
== The club today == The club and its ground are very active. The club now plays in the [[Middlesex County Cricket League]]. [[Middlesex County Cricket Club|Middlesex CCC]], which was also founded by the Walkers, still occasionally plays [[County Championship]], one day and 20/20 matches at the ground.<ref>[http://www.cricketarchive.co.uk/Archive/Scorecards/107/107805.html Scorecard of Middlesex v Leicestershire at Southgate, 2007.]</ref> In 2011, the 1st XI gained promotion to the Middlesex County Cricket League Premier Division, winning the Division Two championship.<ref>[http://www.southgatecc.com/champions/ Southgate CC Website, 2011.]</ref> The club remains in the Premier League at the start of the 2017 season.<ref>http://www.middlesexccl.com/</ref>

{{SLO}} |nearest_city = [[Slovenska Bistrica]] |coordinates = {{coord|46.4382|N|15.4598|E|type:landmark_scale:50000|display=inline}} |vertical = 164 m - (538 ft)
''total'' |top_elevation = 1344 m - (4,408 ft) |base_elevation = 1180 m - (3,870 ft) |skiable_area = {{convert|70|acre|km2}} |number_trails = Total 1,5 km [[File:Ski trail rating symbol blue circle.png|13px]] 0,5 km
[[File:Ski trail rating symbol red circle.png|13px]] 1 km |longest_run = 1 km - (0,62 miles) |liftsystem = 2 total
2 [[surface lifts|surface]] |snowfall = |snowmaking = yes |external_link=[http://www.jakec-sp.si/Default.asp?IDM=0/ jakec-sp.si] |}} '''Trije Kralji Ski Resort''' is a Slovenian family [[ski resort]] located in western part of [[Pohorje]] mountain in municipality of [[Slovenska Bistrica]]. It's 18 km away from closest city Slovenska Bistrica. Resort has two slopes, two lifts and together 1,5 km of skiing terrain and 4 km of cross-country skiing. There are plans to build a new chair-lift and two new slopes. ==Ski slopes== {| border="2" cellpadding="4" cellspacing="0" style="margin:0 1em 0 0; background: #f9f9f9; border: 1px #aaa solid; border-collapse: collapse; font-size: 95%;" |- align=center | '''Name''' | '''Length''' | '''Category''' |- align=right |Črno Jezero |2 x 450m |easy |- align=right |Veliki Vrh |2 x 950m |intermediate |} ==External links== * [http://www.jakec.si/ jakec.si] - official site [[Category:Ski areas and resorts in Slovenia]] {{Slovenia-sports-venue-stub}}
